speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Well see what may be done, so you confess freely;

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: therefore, once more to this Captain Dumain: you

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: have answered to his reputation with the duke and to

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: his valour: what is his honesty?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: He will steal, sir, an egg out of a cloister: for

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: rapes and ravishments he parallels Nessus: he

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: professes not keeping of oaths; in breaking em he

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: is stronger than Hercules: he will lie, sir, with

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: such volubility, that you would think truth were a

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: fool: drunkenness is his best virtue, for he will

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: be swine-drunk; and in his sleep he does little

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: harm, save to his bed-clothes about him; but they

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: know his conditions and lay him in straw. I have but

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: little more to say, sir, of his honesty: he has

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: every thing that an honest man should not have; what

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: an honest man should have, he has nothing.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: I begin to love him for this.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: For this description of thine honesty? A pox upon

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: him for me, hes more and more a cat.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: What say you to his expertness in war?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Faith, sir, he has led the drum before the English

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: tragedians; to belie him, I will not, and more of

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: his soldiership I know not; except, in that country

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: he had the honour to be the officer at a place there

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: called Mile-end, to instruct for the doubling of

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: files: I would do the man what honour I can, but of

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: this I am not certain.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: He hath out-villained villany so far, that the

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: rarity redeems him.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: A pox on him, hes a cat still.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: His qualities being at this poor price, I need not

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: to ask you if gold will corrupt him to revolt.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Sir, for a quart decu he will sell the fee-simple

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: of his salvation, the inheritance of it; and cut the

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: entail from all remainders, and a perpetual

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: succession for it perpetually.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Whats his brother, the other Captain Dumain?

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Why does be ask him of me?

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Whats he?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Een a crow o the same nest; not altogether so

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: great as the first in goodness, but greater a great

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: deal in evil: he excels his brother for a coward,

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: yet his brother is reputed one of the best that is:

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: in a retreat he outruns any lackey; marry, in coming

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: on he has the cramp.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: If your life be saved, will you undertake to betray

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: the Florentine?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Ay, and the captain of his horse, Count Rousillon.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Ill whisper with the general, and know his pleasure.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: [Aside]  Ill no more drumming; a plague of all

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: drums! Only to seem to deserve well, and to

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: beguile the supposition of that lascivious young boy

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: the count, have I run into this danger. Yet who

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: would have suspected an ambush where I was taken?

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: There is no remedy, sir, but you must die: the

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: general says, you that have so traitorously

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: discovered the secrets of your army and made such

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: pestiferous reports of men very nobly held, can

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: serve the world for no honest use; therefore you

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: must die. Come, headsman, off with his head.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: O Lord, sir, let me live, or let me see my death!

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: That shall you, and take your leave of all your friends.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Unblinding him

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: So, look about you: know you any here?

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Good morrow, noble captain.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: God bless you, Captain Parolles.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: God save you, noble captain.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Captain, what greeting will you to my Lord Lafeu?

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: I am for France.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Good captain, will you give me a copy of the sonnet

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: you writ to Diana in behalf of the Count Rousillon?

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: an I were not a very coward, Ild compel it of you:

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: but fare you well.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Exeunt BERTRAM and Lords

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: You are undone, captain, all but your scarf; that

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: has a knot ont yet

text_entry: Who cannot be crushed with a plot?

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: If you could find out a country where but women were

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: that had received so much shame, you might begin an

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: impudent nation. Fare ye well, sir; I am for France

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: too: we shall speak of you there.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Exit with Soldiers

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Yet am I thankful: if my heart were great,

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Twould burst at this. Captain Ill be no more;

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: But I will eat and drink, and sleep as soft

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: As captain shall: simply the thing I am

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Shall make me live. Who knows himself a braggart,

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Let him fear this, for it will come to pass

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: that every braggart shall be found an ass.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Rust, sword? cool, blushes! and, Parolles, live

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Safest in shame! being foold, by foolery thrive!

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Theres place and means for every man alive.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Ill after them.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Exit

text_entry: That you may well perceive I have not wrongd you,

text_entry: Ere I can perfect mine intents, to kneel:

text_entry: And by the leave of my good lord the king,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Well be before our welcome.

speaker: Widow
text_entry: Gentle madam,

speaker: Widow
text_entry: You never had a servant to whose trust

speaker: Widow
text_entry: Your business was more welcome.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Nor you, mistress,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Ever a friend whose thoughts more truly labour

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: To recompense your love: doubt not but heaven

text_entry: Hath brought me up to be your daughters dower,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: As it hath fated her to be my motive

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And helper to a husband. But, O strange men!

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: That can such sweet use make of what they hate,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: When saucy trusting of the cozend thoughts

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Defiles the pitchy night: so lust doth play

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: With what it loathes for that which is away.

text_entry: But more of this hereafter. You, Diana,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Under my poor instructions yet must suffer

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Something in my behalf.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Let death and honesty

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Go with your impositions, I am yours

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Upon your will to suffer.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Yet, I pray you:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: But with the word the time will bring on summer,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: When briers shall have leaves as well as thorns,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And be as sweet as sharp. We must away;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Our wagon is prepared, and time revives us:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Alls well that ends well; still the fines the crown;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Whateer the course, the end is the renown.

text_entry: thousand salads ere we light on such another herb.

text_entry: salad, or rather, the herb of grace.

text_entry: skill in grass.

text_entry: A fool, sir, at a womans service, and a knave at a mans.

text_entry: Your distinction?

text_entry: And I would give his wife my bauble, sir, to do her service.

text_entry: I will subscribe for thee, thou art both knave and fool.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: At your service.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: No, no, no.

text_entry: great a prince as you are.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: is more hotter in France than there.

text_entry: The black prince, sir; alias, the prince of

text_entry: I am a woodland fellow, sir, that always loved a

text_entry: great fire; and the master I speak of ever keeps a

speaker: Clown
text_entry: good fire. But, sure, he is the prince of the

speaker: Clown
text_entry: world; let his nobility remain ins court. I am for

text_entry: leads to the broad gate and the great fire.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Go thy ways, I begin to be aweary of thee; and I

text_entry: with thee. Go thy ways: let my horses be well

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: looked to, without any tricks.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: jades tricks; which are their own right by the law of nature.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: A shrewd knave and an unhappy.

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: So he is. My lord thats gone made himself much

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: sport out of him: by his authority he remains here,

text_entry: which he thinks is a patent for his sauciness; and,

speaker: COUNTESS

speaker: LAFEU

speaker: LAFEU

text_entry: it: and, to stop up the displeasure he hath

speaker: LAFEU

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: happily effected.

speaker: LAFEU

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: intelligence hath seldom failed.

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: die. I have letters that my son will be here

text_entry: to-night: I shall beseech your lordship to remain

speaker: COUNTESS

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: safely be admitted.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Lady, of that I have made a bold charter; but I

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: thank my God it holds yet.

text_entry: half, but his right cheek is worn bare.

speaker: LAFEU

text_entry: ALLS WELL THAT ENDS WELL yet,

text_entry: Though time seem so adverse and means unfit.

speaker: Gentleman
text_entry: Whither I am going.

text_entry: I do beseech you, sir,

text_entry: Since you are like to see the king before me,

text_entry: Commend the paper to his gracious hand,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: I am either maid, or else this old mans wife.

speaker: KING
text_entry: She does abuse our ears: to prison with her.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Good mother, fetch my bail. Stay, royal sir:

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Exit Widow

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: The jeweller that owes the ring is sent for,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: And he shall surety me. But for this lord,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Who hath abused me, as he knows himself,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Though yet he never harmd me, here I quit him:

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: He knows himself my bed he hath defiled;

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: And at that time he got his wife with child:

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Dead though she be, she feels her young one kick:

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: So theres my riddle: one thats dead is quick:

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: And now behold the meaning.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Re-enter Widow, with HELENA

speaker: KING
text_entry: Is there no exorcist

speaker: KING
text_entry: Beguiles the truer office of mine eyes?

speaker: KING
text_entry: Ist real that I see?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: No, my good lord;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Tis but the shadow of a wife you see,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: The name and not the thing.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Both, both. O, pardon!

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: O my good lord, when I was like this maid,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: I found you wondrous kind. There is your ring;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And, look you, heres your letter; this it says:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: When from my finger you can get this ring

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And are by me with child,  and c. This is done:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Will you be mine, now you are doubly won?

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: If she, my liege, can make me know this clearly,

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Ill love her dearly, ever, ever dearly.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: If it appear not plain and prove untrue,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Deadly divorce step between me and you!

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: O my dear mother, do I see you living?

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Mine eyes smell onions; I shall weep anon:

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: To PAROLLES

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Good Tom Drum, lend me a handkercher: so,

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: I thank thee: wait on me home, Ill make sport with thee:

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Let thy courtesies alone, they are scurvy ones.

speaker: KING
text_entry: Let us from point to point this story know,

speaker: KING
text_entry: To make the even truth in pleasure flow.

speaker: KING
text_entry: To DIANA

speaker: KING
text_entry: If thou best yet a fresh uncropped flower,

speaker: KING
text_entry: Choose thou thy husband, and Ill pay thy dower;

speaker: KING
text_entry: For I can guess that by thy honest aid

speaker: KING
text_entry: Thou keepst a wife herself, thyself a maid.

speaker: KING
text_entry: Of that and all the progress, more or less,

speaker: KING
text_entry: Resolvedly more leisure shall express:

speaker: KING
text_entry: All yet seems well; and if it end so meet,

speaker: KING
text_entry: The bitter past, more welcome is the sweet.

speaker: KING
text_entry: Flourish

speaker: KING
text_entry: EPILOGUE

speaker: KING
text_entry: The kings a beggar, now the play is done:

speaker: KING
text_entry: All is well ended, if this suit be won,

speaker: KING
text_entry: That you express content; which we will pay,

speaker: KING
text_entry: With strife to please you, day exceeding day:

speaker: KING
text_entry: Ours be your patience then, and yours our parts;

speaker: KING
text_entry: Your gentle hands lend us, and take our hearts.

speaker: KING
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: KING
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: KING
text_entry: SCENE I. Orchard of Olivers house.

speaker: KING
text_entry: Enter ORLANDO and ADAM

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: As I remember, Adam, it was upon this fashion

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: bequeathed me by will but poor a thousand crowns,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: and, as thou sayest, charged my brother, on his

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: blessing, to breed me well: and there begins my

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: sadness. My brother Jaques he keeps at school, and

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: report speaks goldenly of his profit: for my part,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: he keeps me rustically at home, or, to speak more

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: properly, stays me here at home unkept; for call you

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: that keeping for a gentleman of my birth, that

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: differs not from the stalling of an ox? His horses

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: are bred better; for, besides that they are fair

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: with their feeding, they are taught their manage,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: and to that end riders dearly hired: but I, his

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: brother, gain nothing under him but growth; for the

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: which his animals on his dunghills are as much

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: bound to him as I. Besides this nothing that he so

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: plentifully gives me, the something that nature gave

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: me his countenance seems to take from me: he lets

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: me feed with his hinds, bars me the place of a

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: brother, and, as much as in him lies, mines my

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: gentility with my education. This is it, Adam, that

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: grieves me; and the spirit of my father, which I

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: think is within me, begins to mutiny against this

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: servitude: I will no longer endure it, though yet I

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: know no wise remedy how to avoid it.

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Yonder comes my master, your brother.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Go apart, Adam, and thou shalt hear how he will

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: shake me up.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Enter OLIVER

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Now, sir! what make you here?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Nothing: I am not taught to make any thing.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: What mar you then, sir?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Marry, sir, I am helping you to mar that which God

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: made, a poor unworthy brother of yours, with idleness.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Marry, sir, be better employed, and be naught awhile.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Shall I keep your hogs and eat husks with them?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: What prodigal portion have I spent, that I should

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: come to such penury?

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Know you where your are, sir?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: O, sir, very well; here in your orchard.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Know you before whom, sir?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Ay, better than him I am before knows me. I know

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: you are my eldest brother; and, in the gentle

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: condition of blood, you should so know me. The

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: courtesy of nations allows you my better, in that

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: you are the first-born; but the same tradition

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: takes not away my blood, were there twenty brothers

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: betwixt us: I have as much of my father in me as

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: you; albeit, I confess, your coming before me is

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: nearer to his reverence.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: What, boy!

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Come, come, elder brother, you are too young in this.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Wilt thou lay hands on me, villain?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I am no villain; I am the youngest son of Sir

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Rowland de Boys; he was my father, and he is thrice

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: a villain that says such a father begot villains.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Wert thou not my brother, I would not take this hand

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: from thy throat till this other had pulled out thy

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: tongue for saying so: thou hast railed on thyself.

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Sweet masters, be patient: for your fathers

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: remembrance, be at accord.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Let me go, I say.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I will not, till I please: you shall hear me. My

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: father charged you in his will to give me good

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: education: you have trained me like a peasant,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: obscuring and hiding from me all gentleman-like

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: qualities. The spirit of my father grows strong in

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: me, and I will no longer endure it: therefore allow

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: me such exercises as may become a gentleman, or

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: give me the poor allottery my father left me by

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: testament; with that I will go buy my fortunes.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: And what wilt thou do? beg, when that is spent?

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Well, sir, get you in: I will not long be troubled

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: with you; you shall have some part of your will: I

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: pray you, leave me.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I will no further offend you than becomes me for my good.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Get you with him, you old dog.

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Is old dog my reward? Most true, I have lost my

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: teeth in your service. God be with my old master!

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: he would not have spoke such a word.

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Exeunt ORLANDO and ADAM

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Is it even so? begin you to grow upon me? I will

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: physic your rankness, and yet give no thousand

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: crowns neither. Holla, Dennis!

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Enter DENNIS

speaker: DENNIS
text_entry: Calls your worship?

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Was not Charles, the dukes wrestler, here to speak with me?

speaker: DENNIS
text_entry: So please you, he is here at the door and importunes

speaker: DENNIS
text_entry: access to you.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Call him in.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Exit DENNIS

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Twill be a good way; and to-morrow the wrestling is.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Enter CHARLES

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Good morrow to your worship.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Good Monsieur Charles, whats the new news at the

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: new court?

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Theres no news at the court, sir, but the old news:

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: that is, the old duke is banished by his younger

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: brother the new duke; and three or four loving lords

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: have put themselves into voluntary exile with him,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: whose lands and revenues enrich the new duke;

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: therefore he gives them good leave to wander.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Can you tell if Rosalind, the dukes daughter, be

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: banished with her father?

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: O, no; for the dukes daughter, her cousin, so loves

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: her, being ever from their cradles bred together,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: that she would have followed her exile, or have died

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: to stay behind her. She is at the court, and no

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: less beloved of her uncle than his own daughter; and

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: never two ladies loved as they do.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Where will the old duke live?

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: They say he is already in the forest of Arden, and

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: a many merry men with him; and there they live like

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: the old Robin Hood of England: they say many young

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: gentlemen flock to him every day, and fleet the time

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: carelessly, as they did in the golden world.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: What, you wrestle to-morrow before the new duke?

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Marry, do I, sir; and I came to acquaint you with a

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: matter. I am given, sir, secretly to understand

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: that your younger brother Orlando hath a disposition

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: to come in disguised against me to try a fall.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: To-morrow, sir, I wrestle for my credit; and he that

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: escapes me without some broken limb shall acquit him

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: well. Your brother is but young and tender; and,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: for your love, I would be loath to foil him, as I

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: must, for my own honour, if he come in: therefore,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: out of my love to you, I came hither to acquaint you

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: withal, that either you might stay him from his

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: intendment or brook such disgrace well as he shall

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: run into, in that it is a thing of his own search

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: and altogether against my will.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Charles, I thank thee for thy love to me, which

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: thou shalt find I will most kindly requite. I had

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: myself notice of my brothers purpose herein and

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: have by underhand means laboured to dissuade him from

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: it, but he is resolute. Ill tell thee, Charles:

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: it is the stubbornest young fellow of France, full

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: of ambition, an envious emulator of every mans

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: good parts, a secret and villanous contriver against

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: me his natural brother: therefore use thy

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: discretion; I had as lief thou didst break his neck

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: as his finger. And thou wert best look tot; for if

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: thou dost him any slight disgrace or if he do not

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: mightily grace himself on thee, he will practise

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: against thee by poison, entrap thee by some

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: treacherous device and never leave thee till he

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: hath taen thy life by some indirect means or other;

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: for, I assure thee, and almost with tears I speak

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: it, there is not one so young and so villanous this

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: day living. I speak but brotherly of him; but

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: should I anatomize him to thee as he is, I must

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: blush and weep and thou must look pale and wonder.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: I am heartily glad I came hither to you. If he come

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: to-morrow, Ill give him his payment: if ever he go

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: alone again, Ill never wrestle for prize more: and

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: so God keep your worship!

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Farewell, good Charles.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Exit CHARLES

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Now will I stir this gamester: I hope I shall see

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: an end of him; for my soul, yet I know not why,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: hates nothing more than he. Yet hes gentle, never

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: schooled and yet learned, full of noble device, of

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: all sorts enchantingly beloved, and indeed so much

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: in the heart of the world, and especially of my own

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: people, who best know him, that I am altogether

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: misprised: but it shall not be so long; this

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: wrestler shall clear all: nothing remains but that

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: I kindle the boy thither; which now Ill go about.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Exit

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: SCENE II. Lawn before the Dukes palace.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Enter CELIA and ROSALIND

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: I pray thee, Rosalind, sweet my coz, be merry.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Dear Celia, I show more mirth than I am mistress of;

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: and would you yet I were merrier? Unless you could

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: teach me to forget a banished father, you must not

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: learn me how to remember any extraordinary pleasure.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Herein I see thou lovest me not with the full weight

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: that I love thee. If my uncle, thy banished father,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: had banished thy uncle, the duke my father, so thou

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: hadst been still with me, I could have taught my

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: love to take thy father for mine: so wouldst thou,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: if the truth of thy love to me were so righteously

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: tempered as mine is to thee.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Well, I will forget the condition of my estate, to

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: rejoice in yours.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: You know my father hath no child but I, nor none is

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: like to have: and, truly, when he dies, thou shalt

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: be his heir, for what he hath taken away from thy

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: father perforce, I will render thee again in

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: affection; by mine honour, I will; and when I break

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: that oath, let me turn monster: therefore, my

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: sweet Rose, my dear Rose, be merry.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: From henceforth I will, coz, and devise sports. Let

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: me see; what think you of falling in love?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Marry, I prithee, do, to make sport withal: but

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: love no man in good earnest; nor no further in sport

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: neither than with safety of a pure blush thou mayst

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: in honour come off again.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: What shall be our sport, then?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Let us sit and mock the good housewife Fortune from

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: her wheel, that her gifts may henceforth be bestowed equally.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I would we could do so, for her benefits are

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: mightily misplaced, and the bountiful blind woman

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: doth most mistake in her gifts to women.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Tis true; for those that she makes fair she scarce

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: makes honest, and those that she makes honest she

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: makes very ill-favouredly.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Nay, now thou goest from Fortunes office to

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Natures: Fortune reigns in gifts of the world,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: not in the lineaments of Nature.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Enter TOUCHSTONE

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: No? when Nature hath made a fair creature, may she

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: not by Fortune fall into the fire? Though Nature

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: hath given us wit to flout at Fortune, hath not

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Fortune sent in this fool to cut off the argument?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Indeed, there is Fortune too hard for Nature, when

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Fortune makes Natures natural the cutter-off of

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Natures wit.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Peradventure this is not Fortunes work neither, but

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Natures; who perceiveth our natural wits too dull

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: to reason of such goddesses and hath sent this

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: natural for our whetstone; for always the dulness of

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: the fool is the whetstone of the wits. How now,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: wit! whither wander you?

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Mistress, you must come away to your father.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Were you made the messenger?

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: No, by mine honour, but I was bid to come for you.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Where learned you that oath, fool?

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Of a certain knight that swore by his honour they

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: were good pancakes and swore by his honour the

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: mustard was naught: now Ill stand to it, the

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: pancakes were naught and the mustard was good, and

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: yet was not the knight forsworn.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: How prove you that, in the great heap of your

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: knowledge?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Ay, marry, now unmuzzle your wisdom.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Stand you both forth now: stroke your chins, and

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: swear by your beards that I am a knave.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: By our beards, if we had them, thou art.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: By my knavery, if I had it, then I were; but if you

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: swear by that that is not, you are not forsworn: no

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: more was this knight swearing by his honour, for he

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: never had any; or if he had, he had sworn it away

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: before ever he saw those pancakes or that mustard.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Prithee, who ist that thou meanest?

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: One that old Frederick, your father, loves.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: My fathers love is enough to honour him: enough!

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: speak no more of him; youll be whipped for taxation

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: one of these days.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: The more pity, that fools may not speak wisely what

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: wise men do foolishly.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: By my troth, thou sayest true; for since the little

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: wit that fools have was silenced, the little foolery

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: that wise men have makes a great show. Here comes

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Monsieur Le Beau.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: With his mouth full of news.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Which he will put on us, as pigeons feed their young.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Then shall we be news-crammed.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: All the better; we shall be the more marketable.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Enter LE BEAU

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Bon jour, Monsieur Le Beau: whats the news?

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: Fair princess, you have lost much good sport.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Sport! of what colour?

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: What colour, madam! how shall I answer you?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: As wit and fortune will.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Or as the Destinies decree.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Well said: that was laid on with a trowel.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Nay, if I keep not my rank,--

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Thou losest thy old smell.

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: You amaze me, ladies: I would have told you of good

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: wrestling, which you have lost the sight of.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: You tell us the manner of the wrestling.

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: I will tell you the beginning; and, if it please

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: your ladyships, you may see the end; for the best is

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: yet to do; and here, where you are, they are coming

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: to perform it.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Well, the beginning, that is dead and buried.

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: There comes an old man and his three sons,--

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: I could match this beginning with an old tale.

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: Three proper young men, of excellent growth and presence.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: With bills on their necks, Be it known unto all men

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: by these presents.

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: The eldest of the three wrestled with Charles, the

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: dukes wrestler; which Charles in a moment threw him

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: and broke three of his ribs, that there is little

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: hope of life in him: so he served the second, and

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: so the third. Yonder they lie; the poor old man,

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: their father, making such pitiful dole over them

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: that all the beholders take his part with weeping.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Alas!

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: But what is the sport, monsieur, that the ladies

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: have lost?

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: Why, this that I speak of.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Thus men may grow wiser every day: it is the first

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: time that ever I heard breaking of ribs was sport

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: for ladies.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Or I, I promise thee.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: But is there any else longs to see this broken music

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: in his sides? is there yet another dotes upon

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: rib-breaking? Shall we see this wrestling, cousin?

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: You must, if you stay here; for here is the place

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: appointed for the wrestling, and they are ready to

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: perform it.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Yonder, sure, they are coming: let us now stay and see it.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Flourish. Enter DUKE FREDERICK, Lords, ORLANDO, CHARLES, and Attendants

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Come on: since the youth will not be entreated, his

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: own peril on his forwardness.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Is yonder the man?

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: Even he, madam.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Alas, he is too young! yet he looks successfully.

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: How now, daughter and cousin! are you crept hither

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: to see the wrestling?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Ay, my liege, so please you give us leave.

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: You will take little delight in it, I can tell you;

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: there is such odds in the man. In pity of the

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: challengers youth I would fain dissuade him, but he

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: will not be entreated. Speak to him, ladies; see if

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: you can move him.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Call him hither, good Monsieur Le Beau.

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Do so: Ill not be by.

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: Monsieur the challenger, the princesses call for you.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I attend them with all respect and duty.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Young man, have you challenged Charles the wrestler?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: No, fair princess; he is the general challenger: I

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: come but in, as others do, to try with him the

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: strength of my youth.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Young gentleman, your spirits are too bold for your

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: years. You have seen cruel proof of this mans

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: strength: if you saw yourself with your eyes or

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: knew yourself with your judgment, the fear of your

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: adventure would counsel you to a more equal

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: enterprise. We pray you, for your own sake, to

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: embrace your own safety and give over this attempt.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Do, young sir; your reputation shall not therefore

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: be misprised: we will make it our suit to the duke

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: that the wrestling might not go forward.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I beseech you, punish me not with your hard

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: thoughts; wherein I confess me much guilty, to deny

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: so fair and excellent ladies any thing. But let

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: your fair eyes and gentle wishes go with me to my

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: trial: wherein if I be foiled, there is but one

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: shamed that was never gracious; if killed, but one

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: dead that was willing to be so: I shall do my

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: friends no wrong, for I have none to lament me, the

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: world no injury, for in it I have nothing; only in

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: the world I fill up a place, which may be better

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: supplied when I have made it empty.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: The little strength that I have, I would it were with you.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: And mine, to eke out hers.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Fare you well: pray heaven I be deceived in you!

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Your hearts desires be with you!

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Come, where is this young gallant that is so

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: desirous to lie with his mother earth?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Ready, sir; but his will hath in it a more modest working.

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: You shall try but one fall.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: No, I warrant your grace, you shall not entreat him

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: to a second, that have so mightily persuaded him

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: from a first.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: An you mean to mock me after, you should not have

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: mocked me before: but come your ways.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Now Hercules be thy speed, young man!

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: I would I were invisible, to catch the strong

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: fellow by the leg.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: They wrestle

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: O excellent young man!

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: If I had a thunderbolt in mine eye, I can tell who

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: should down.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Shout. CHARLES is thrown

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: No more, no more.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Yes, I beseech your grace: I am not yet well breathed.

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: How dost thou, Charles?

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: He cannot speak, my lord.

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Bear him away. What is thy name, young man?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Orlando, my liege; the youngest son of Sir Rowland de Boys.

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: I would thou hadst been son to some man else:

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: The world esteemd thy father honourable,

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: But I did find him still mine enemy:

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Thou shouldst have better pleased me with this deed,

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Hadst thou descended from another house.

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: But fare thee well; thou art a gallant youth:

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: I would thou hadst told me of another father.

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Exeunt DUKE FREDERICK, train, and LE BEAU

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Were I my father, coz, would I do this?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I am more proud to be Sir Rowlands son,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: His youngest son; and would not change that calling,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: To be adopted heir to Frederick.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: My father loved Sir Rowland as his soul,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And all the world was of my fathers mind:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Had I before known this young man his son,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I should have given him tears unto entreaties,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Ere he should thus have ventured.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Gentle cousin,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Let us go thank him and encourage him:

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: My fathers rough and envious disposition

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Sticks me at heart. Sir, you have well deserved:

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: If you do keep your promises in love

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: But justly, as you have exceeded all promise,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Your mistress shall be happy.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Gentleman,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Giving him a chain from her neck

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Wear this for me, one out of suits with fortune,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: That could give more, but that her hand lacks means.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Shall we go, coz?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Ay. Fare you well, fair gentleman.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Can I not say, I thank you? My better parts

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Are all thrown down, and that which here stands up

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Is but a quintain, a mere lifeless block.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: He calls us back: my pride fell with my fortunes;

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Ill ask him what he would. Did you call, sir?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Sir, you have wrestled well and overthrown

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: More than your enemies.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Will you go, coz?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Have with you. Fare you well.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Exeunt ROSALIND and CELIA

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: What passion hangs these weights upon my tongue?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I cannot speak to her, yet she urged conference.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: O poor Orlando, thou art overthrown!

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Or Charles or something weaker masters thee.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Re-enter LE BEAU

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: Good sir, I do in friendship counsel you

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: To leave this place. Albeit you have deserved

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: High commendation, true applause and love,

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: Yet such is now the dukes condition

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: That he misconstrues all that you have done.

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: The duke is humorous; what he is indeed,

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: More suits you to conceive than I to speak of.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I thank you, sir: and, pray you, tell me this:

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Which of the two was daughter of the duke

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: That here was at the wrestling?

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: Neither his daughter, if we judge by manners;

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: But yet indeed the lesser is his daughter

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: The other is daughter to the banishd duke,

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: And here detaind by her usurping uncle,

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: To keep his daughter company; whose loves

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: Are dearer than the natural bond of sisters.

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: But I can tell you that of late this duke

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: Hath taen displeasure gainst his gentle niece,

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: Grounded upon no other argument

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: But that the people praise her for her virtues

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: And pity her for her good fathers sake;

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: And, on my life, his malice gainst the lady

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: Will suddenly break forth. Sir, fare you well:

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: Hereafter, in a better world than this,

speaker: LE BEAU
text_entry: I shall desire more love and knowledge of you.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I rest much bounden to you: fare you well.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Exit LE BEAU

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Thus must I from the smoke into the smother;

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: From tyrant duke unto a tyrant brother:

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: But heavenly Rosalind!

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: SCENE III. A room in the palace.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Enter CELIA and ROSALIND

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Why, cousin! why, Rosalind! Cupid have mercy! not a word?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Not one to throw at a dog.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: No, thy words are too precious to be cast away upon

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: curs; throw some of them at me; come, lame me with reasons.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Then there were two cousins laid up; when the one

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: should be lamed with reasons and the other mad

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: without any.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: But is all this for your father?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: No, some of it is for my childs father. O, how

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: full of briers is this working-day world!

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: They are but burs, cousin, thrown upon thee in

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: holiday foolery: if we walk not in the trodden

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: paths our very petticoats will catch them.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I could shake them off my coat: these burs are in my heart.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Hem them away.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I would try, if I could cry hem and have him.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Come, come, wrestle with thy affections.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: O, they take the part of a better wrestler than myself!

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: O, a good wish upon you! you will try in time, in

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: despite of a fall. But, turning these jests out of

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: service, let us talk in good earnest: is it

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: possible, on such a sudden, you should fall into so

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: strong a liking with old Sir Rowlands youngest son?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: The duke my father loved his father dearly.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Doth it therefore ensue that you should love his son

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: dearly? By this kind of chase, I should hate him,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: for my father hated his father dearly; yet I hate

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: not Orlando.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: No, faith, hate him not, for my sake.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Why should I not? doth he not deserve well?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Let me love him for that, and do you love him

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: because I do. Look, here comes the duke.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: With his eyes full of anger.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Enter DUKE FREDERICK, with Lords

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Mistress, dispatch you with your safest haste

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: And get you from our court.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Me, uncle?

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: You, cousin

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Within these ten days if that thou best found

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: So near our public court as twenty miles,

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Thou diest for it.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I do beseech your grace,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Let me the knowledge of my fault bear with me:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: If with myself I hold intelligence

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Or have acquaintance with mine own desires,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: If that I do not dream or be not frantic,--

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: As I do trust I am not--then, dear uncle,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Never so much as in a thought unborn

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Did I offend your highness.

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Thus do all traitors:

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: If their purgation did consist in words,

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: They are as innocent as grace itself:

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Let it suffice thee that I trust thee not.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Yet your mistrust cannot make me a traitor:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Tell me whereon the likelihood depends.

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Thou art thy fathers daughter; theres enough.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: So was I when your highness took his dukedom;

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: So was I when your highness banishd him:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Treason is not inherited, my lord;

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Or, if we did derive it from our friends,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Whats that to me? my father was no traitor:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Then, good my liege, mistake me not so much

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: To think my poverty is treacherous.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Dear sovereign, hear me speak.

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Ay, Celia; we stayd her for your sake,

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Else had she with her father ranged along.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: I did not then entreat to have her stay;

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: It was your pleasure and your own remorse:

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: I was too young that time to value her;

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: But now I know her: if she be a traitor,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Why so am I; we still have slept together,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Rose at an instant, learnd, playd, eat together,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: And wheresoever we went, like Junos swans,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Still we went coupled and inseparable.

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: She is too subtle for thee; and her smoothness,

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Her very silence and her patience

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Speak to the people, and they pity her.

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Thou art a fool: she robs thee of thy name;

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: And thou wilt show more bright and seem more virtuous

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: When she is gone. Then open not thy lips:

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Firm and irrevocable is my doom

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Which I have passd upon her; she is banishd.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Pronounce that sentence then on me, my liege:

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: I cannot live out of her company.

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: You are a fool. You, niece, provide yourself:

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: If you outstay the time, upon mine honour,

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: And in the greatness of my word, you die.

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Exeunt DUKE FREDERICK and Lords

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: O my poor Rosalind, whither wilt thou go?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Wilt thou change fathers? I will give thee mine.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: I charge thee, be not thou more grieved than I am.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I have more cause.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Thou hast not, cousin;

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Prithee be cheerful: knowst thou not, the duke

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Hath banishd me, his daughter?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: That he hath not.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: No, hath not? Rosalind lacks then the love

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Which teacheth thee that thou and I am one:

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Shall we be sunderd? shall we part, sweet girl?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: No: let my father seek another heir.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Therefore devise with me how we may fly,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Whither to go and what to bear with us;

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: And do not seek to take your change upon you,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: To bear your griefs yourself and leave me out;

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: For, by this heaven, now at our sorrows pale,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Say what thou canst, Ill go along with thee.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Why, whither shall we go?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: To seek my uncle in the forest of Arden.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Alas, what danger will it be to us,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Maids as we are, to travel forth so far!

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Beauty provoketh thieves sooner than gold.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Ill put myself in poor and mean attire

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: And with a kind of umber smirch my face;

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: The like do you: so shall we pass along

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: And never stir assailants.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Were it not better,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Because that I am more than common tall,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: That I did suit me all points like a man?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: A gallant curtle-axe upon my thigh,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: A boar-spear in my hand; and--in my heart

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Lie there what hidden womans fear there will--

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Well have a swashing and a martial outside,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: As many other mannish cowards have

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: That do outface it with their semblances.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: What shall I call thee when thou art a man?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Ill have no worse a name than Joves own page;

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And therefore look you call me Ganymede.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: But what will you be calld?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Something that hath a reference to my state

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: No longer Celia, but Aliena.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: But, cousin, what if we assayd to steal

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: The clownish fool out of your fathers court?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Would he not be a comfort to our travel?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Hell go along oer the wide world with me;

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Leave me alone to woo him. Lets away,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: And get our jewels and our wealth together,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Devise the fittest time and safest way

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: To hide us from pursuit that will be made

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: After my flight. Now go we in content

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: To liberty and not to banishment.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: ACT II

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: SCENE I. The Forest of Arden.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Enter DUKE SENIOR, AMIENS, and two or three Lords, like foresters

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Now, my co-mates and brothers in exile,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Hath not old custom made this life more sweet

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Than that of painted pomp? Are not these woods

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: More free from peril than the envious court?

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Here feel we but the penalty of Adam,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: The seasons difference, as the icy fang

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: And churlish chiding of the winters wind,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Which, when it bites and blows upon my body,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Even till I shrink with cold, I smile and say

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: This is no flattery: these are counsellors

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: That feelingly persuade me what I am.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Sweet are the uses of adversity,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Which, like the toad, ugly and venomous,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Wears yet a precious jewel in his head;

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: And this our life exempt from public haunt

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Finds tongues in trees, books in the running brooks,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Sermons in stones and good in every thing.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: I would not change it.

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Happy is your grace,

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: That can translate the stubbornness of fortune

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Into so quiet and so sweet a style.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Come, shall we go and kill us venison?

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: And yet it irks me the poor dappled fools,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Being native burghers of this desert city,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Should in their own confines with forked heads

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Have their round haunches gored.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Indeed, my lord,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: The melancholy Jaques grieves at that,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: And, in that kind, swears you do more usurp

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Than doth your brother that hath banishd you.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: To-day my Lord of Amiens and myself

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Did steal behind him as he lay along

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Under an oak whose antique root peeps out

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Upon the brook that brawls along this wood:

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: To the which place a poor sequesterd stag,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: That from the hunters aim had taen a hurt,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Did come to languish, and indeed, my lord,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: The wretched animal heaved forth such groans

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: That their discharge did stretch his leathern coat

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Almost to bursting, and the big round tears

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Coursed one another down his innocent nose

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: In piteous chase; and thus the hairy fool

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Much marked of the melancholy Jaques,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Stood on the extremest verge of the swift brook,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Augmenting it with tears.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: But what said Jaques?

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Did he not moralize this spectacle?

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: O, yes, into a thousand similes.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: First, for his weeping into the needless stream;

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Poor deer, quoth he, thou makest a testament

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: As worldlings do, giving thy sum of more

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: To that which had too much: then, being there alone,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Left and abandond of his velvet friends,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Tis right: quoth he; thus misery doth part

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: The flux of company: anon a careless herd,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Full of the pasture, jumps along by him

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: And never stays to greet him; Ay quoth Jaques,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Sweep on, you fat and greasy citizens;

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Tis just the fashion: wherefore do you look

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Upon that poor and broken bankrupt there?

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Thus most invectively he pierceth through

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: The body of the country, city, court,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Yea, and of this our life, swearing that we

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Are mere usurpers, tyrants and whats worse,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: To fright the animals and to kill them up

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: In their assignd and native dwelling-place.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: And did you leave him in this contemplation?

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: We did, my lord, weeping and commenting

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Upon the sobbing deer.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Show me the place:

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: I love to cope him in these sullen fits,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: For then hes full of matter.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Ill bring you to him straight.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: SCENE II. A room in the palace.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Enter DUKE FREDERICK, with Lords

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Can it be possible that no man saw them?

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: It cannot be: some villains of my court

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Are of consent and sufferance in this.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: I cannot hear of any that did see her.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: The ladies, her attendants of her chamber,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Saw her abed, and in the morning early

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: They found the bed untreasured of their mistress.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: My lord, the roynish clown, at whom so oft

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Your grace was wont to laugh, is also missing.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Hisperia, the princess gentlewoman,

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Confesses that she secretly oerheard

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Your daughter and her cousin much commend

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: The parts and graces of the wrestler

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: That did but lately foil the sinewy Charles;

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: And she believes, wherever they are gone,

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: That youth is surely in their company.

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Send to his brother; fetch that gallant hither;

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: If he be absent, bring his brother to me;

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Ill make him find him: do this suddenly,

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: And let not search and inquisition quail

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: To bring again these foolish runaways.

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: SCENE III. Before OLIVERS house.

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Enter ORLANDO and ADAM, meeting

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Whos there?

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: What, my young master? O, my gentle master!

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: O my sweet master! O you memory

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Of old Sir Rowland! why, what make you here?

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Why are you virtuous? why do people love you?

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: And wherefore are you gentle, strong and valiant?

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Why would you be so fond to overcome

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: The bonny priser of the humorous duke?

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Your praise is come too swiftly home before you.

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Know you not, master, to some kind of men

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Their graces serve them but as enemies?

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: No more do yours: your virtues, gentle master,

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Are sanctified and holy traitors to you.

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: O, what a world is this, when what is comely

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Envenoms him that bears it!

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Why, whats the matter?

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: O unhappy youth!

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Come not within these doors; within this roof

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: The enemy of all your graces lives:

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Your brother--no, no brother; yet the son--

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Yet not the son, I will not call him son

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Of him I was about to call his father--

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Hath heard your praises, and this night he means

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: To burn the lodging where you use to lie

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: And you within it: if he fail of that,

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: He will have other means to cut you off.

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: I overheard him and his practises.

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: This is no place; this house is but a butchery:

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Abhor it, fear it, do not enter it.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Why, whither, Adam, wouldst thou have me go?

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: No matter whither, so you come not here.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: What, wouldst thou have me go and beg my food?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Or with a base and boisterous sword enforce

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: A thievish living on the common road?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: This I must do, or know not what to do:

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Yet this I will not do, do how I can;

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I rather will subject me to the malice

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Of a diverted blood and bloody brother.

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: But do not so. I have five hundred crowns,

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: The thrifty hire I saved under your father,

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Which I did store to be my foster-nurse

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: When service should in my old limbs lie lame

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: And unregarded age in corners thrown:

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Take that, and He that doth the ravens feed,

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Yea, providently caters for the sparrow,

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Be comfort to my age! Here is the gold;

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: And all this I give you. Let me be your servant:

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Though I look old, yet I am strong and lusty;

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: For in my youth I never did apply

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Hot and rebellious liquors in my blood,

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Nor did not with unbashful forehead woo

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: The means of weakness and debility;

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Therefore my age is as a lusty winter,

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Frosty, but kindly: let me go with you;

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Ill do the service of a younger man

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: In all your business and necessities.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: O good old man, how well in thee appears

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: The constant service of the antique world,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: When service sweat for duty, not for meed!

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Thou art not for the fashion of these times,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Where none will sweat but for promotion,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And having that, do choke their service up

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Even with the having: it is not so with thee.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: But, poor old man, thou prunest a rotten tree,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: That cannot so much as a blossom yield

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: In lieu of all thy pains and husbandry

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: But come thy ways; well go along together,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And ere we have thy youthful wages spent,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Well light upon some settled low content.

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Master, go on, and I will follow thee,

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: To the last gasp, with truth and loyalty.

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: From seventeen years till now almost fourscore

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Here lived I, but now live here no more.

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: At seventeen years many their fortunes seek;

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: But at fourscore it is too late a week:

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Yet fortune cannot recompense me better

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Than to die well and not my masters debtor.

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: SCENE IV. The Forest of Arden.

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Enter ROSALIND for Ganymede, CELIA for Aliena, and TOUCHSTONE

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: O Jupiter, how weary are my spirits!

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: I care not for my spirits, if my legs were not weary.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I could find in my heart to disgrace my mans

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: apparel and to cry like a woman; but I must comfort

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: the weaker vessel, as doublet and hose ought to show

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: itself courageous to petticoat: therefore courage,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: good Aliena!

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: I pray you, bear with me; I cannot go no further.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: For my part, I had rather bear with you than bear

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: you; yet I should bear no cross if I did bear you,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: for I think you have no money in your purse.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Well, this is the forest of Arden.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Ay, now am I in Arden; the more fool I; when I was

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: at home, I was in a better place: but travellers

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: must be content.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Ay, be so, good Touchstone.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Enter CORIN and SILVIUS

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Look you, who comes here; a young man and an old in

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: solemn talk.

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: That is the way to make her scorn you still.

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: O Corin, that thou knewst how I do love her!

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: I partly guess; for I have loved ere now.

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: No, Corin, being old, thou canst not guess,

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Though in thy youth thou wast as true a lover

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: As ever sighd upon a midnight pillow:

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: But if thy love were ever like to mine--

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: As sure I think did never man love so--

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: How many actions most ridiculous

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Hast thou been drawn to by thy fantasy?

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Into a thousand that I have forgotten.

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: O, thou didst then neer love so heartily!

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: If thou rememberst not the slightest folly

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: That ever love did make thee run into,

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Thou hast not loved:

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Or if thou hast not sat as I do now,

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Wearying thy hearer in thy mistress praise,

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Thou hast not loved:

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Or if thou hast not broke from company

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Abruptly, as my passion now makes me,

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Thou hast not loved.

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: O Phebe, Phebe, Phebe!

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Alas, poor shepherd! searching of thy wound,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I have by hard adventure found mine own.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: And I mine. I remember, when I was in love I broke

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: my sword upon a stone and bid him take that for

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: coming a-night to Jane Smile; and I remember the

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: kissing of her batlet and the cows dugs that her

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: pretty chopt hands had milked; and I remember the

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: wooing of a peascod instead of her, from whom I took

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: two cods and, giving her them again, said with

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: weeping tears Wear these for my sake. We that are

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: true lovers run into strange capers; but as all is

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: mortal in nature, so is all nature in love mortal in folly.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Thou speakest wiser than thou art ware of.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Nay, I shall neer be ware of mine own wit till I

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: break my shins against it.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Jove, Jove! this shepherds passion

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Is much upon my fashion.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: And mine; but it grows something stale with me.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: I pray you, one of you question yond man

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: If he for gold will give us any food:

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: I faint almost to death.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Holla, you clown!

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Peace, fool: hes not thy kinsman.

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Who calls?

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Your betters, sir.

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Else are they very wretched.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Peace, I say. Good even to you, friend.

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: And to you, gentle sir, and to you all.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I prithee, shepherd, if that love or gold

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Can in this desert place buy entertainment,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Bring us where we may rest ourselves and feed:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Heres a young maid with travel much oppressd

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And faints for succor.

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Fair sir, I pity her

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: And wish, for her sake more than for mine own,

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: My fortunes were more able to relieve her;

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: But I am shepherd to another man

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: And do not shear the fleeces that I graze:

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: My master is of churlish disposition

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: And little recks to find the way to heaven

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: By doing deeds of hospitality:

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Besides, his cote, his flocks and bounds of feed

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Are now on sale, and at our sheepcote now,

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: By reason of his absence, there is nothing

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: That you will feed on; but what is, come see.

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: And in my voice most welcome shall you be.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: What is he that shall buy his flock and pasture?

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: That young swain that you saw here but erewhile,

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: That little cares for buying any thing.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I pray thee, if it stand with honesty,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Buy thou the cottage, pasture and the flock,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And thou shalt have to pay for it of us.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: And we will mend thy wages. I like this place.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: And willingly could waste my time in it.

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Assuredly the thing is to be sold:

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Go with me: if you like upon report

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: The soil, the profit and this kind of life,

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: I will your very faithful feeder be

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: And buy it with your gold right suddenly.

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: SCENE V. The Forest.

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Enter AMIENS, JAQUES, and others

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: SONG.

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Under the greenwood tree

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Who loves to lie with me,

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: And turn his merry note

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Unto the sweet birds throat,

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Come hither, come hither, come hither:

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Here shall he see No enemy

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: But winter and rough weather.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: More, more, I prithee, more.

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: It will make you melancholy, Monsieur Jaques.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: I thank it. More, I prithee, more. I can suck

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: melancholy out of a song, as a weasel sucks eggs.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: More, I prithee, more.

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: My voice is ragged: I know I cannot please you.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: I do not desire you to please me; I do desire you to

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: sing. Come, more; another stanzo: call you em stanzos?

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: What you will, Monsieur Jaques.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Nay, I care not for their names; they owe me

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: nothing. Will you sing?

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: More at your request than to please myself.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Well then, if ever I thank any man, Ill thank you;

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: but that they call compliment is like the encounter

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: of two dog-apes, and when a man thanks me heartily,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: methinks I have given him a penny and he renders me

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: the beggarly thanks. Come, sing; and you that will

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: not, hold your tongues.

speaker: AMIENS
