text_entry: Well, Ill end the song. Sirs, cover the while; the

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: duke will drink under this tree. He hath been all

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: this day to look you.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And I have been all this day to avoid him. He is

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: too disputable for my company: I think of as many

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: matters as he, but I give heaven thanks and make no

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: boast of them. Come, warble, come.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: SONG.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Who doth ambition shun

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: All together here

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And loves to live i the sun,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Seeking the food he eats

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And pleased with what he gets,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Come hither, come hither, come hither:

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Here shall he see No enemy

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: But winter and rough weather.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Ill give you a verse to this note that I made

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: yesterday in despite of my invention.

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: And Ill sing it.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Thus it goes:--

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: If it do come to pass

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: That any man turn ass,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Leaving his wealth and ease,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: A stubborn will to please,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Ducdame, ducdame, ducdame:

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Here shall he see

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Gross fools as he,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: An if he will come to me.

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Whats that ducdame?

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Tis a Greek invocation, to call fools into a

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: circle. Ill go sleep, if I can; if I cannot, Ill

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: rail against all the first-born of Egypt.

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: And Ill go seek the duke: his banquet is prepared.

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Exeunt severally

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: SCENE VI. The forest.

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Enter ORLANDO and ADAM

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Dear master, I can go no further. O, I die for food!

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: Here lie I down, and measure out my grave. Farewell,

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: kind master.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Why, how now, Adam! no greater heart in thee? Live

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: a little; comfort a little; cheer thyself a little.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: If this uncouth forest yield any thing savage, I

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: will either be food for it or bring it for food to

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: thee. Thy conceit is nearer death than thy powers.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: For my sake be comfortable; hold death awhile at

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: the arms end: I will here be with thee presently;

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: and if I bring thee not something to eat, I will

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: give thee leave to die: but if thou diest before I

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: come, thou art a mocker of my labour. Well said!

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: thou lookest cheerly, and Ill be with thee quickly.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Yet thou liest in the bleak air: come, I will bear

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: thee to some shelter; and thou shalt not die for

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: lack of a dinner, if there live any thing in this

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: desert. Cheerly, good Adam!

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: SCENE VII. The forest.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: A table set out. Enter DUKE SENIOR, AMIENS, and Lords like outlaws

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: I think he be transformd into a beast;

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: For I can no where find him like a man.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: My lord, he is but even now gone hence:

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Here was he merry, hearing of a song.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: If he, compact of jars, grow musical,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: We shall have shortly discord in the spheres.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Go, seek him: tell him I would speak with him.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Enter JAQUES

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: He saves my labour by his own approach.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Why, how now, monsieur! what a life is this,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: That your poor friends must woo your company?

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: What, you look merrily!

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: A fool, a fool! I met a fool i the forest,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: A motley fool; a miserable world!

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: As I do live by food, I met a fool

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Who laid him down and baskd him in the sun,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And raild on Lady Fortune in good terms,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: In good set terms and yet a motley fool.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Good morrow, fool, quoth I. No, sir, quoth he,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Call me not fool till heaven hath sent me fortune:

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And then he drew a dial from his poke,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And, looking on it with lack-lustre eye,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Says very wisely, It is ten oclock:

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Thus we may see, quoth he, how the world wags:

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Tis but an hour ago since it was nine,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And after one hour more twill be eleven;

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And so, from hour to hour, we ripe and ripe,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And then, from hour to hour, we rot and rot;

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And thereby hangs a tale. When I did hear

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: The motley fool thus moral on the time,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: My lungs began to crow like chanticleer,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: That fools should be so deep-contemplative,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And I did laugh sans intermission

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: An hour by his dial. O noble fool!

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: A worthy fool! Motleys the only wear.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: What fool is this?

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: O worthy fool! One that hath been a courtier,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And says, if ladies be but young and fair,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: They have the gift to know it: and in his brain,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Which is as dry as the remainder biscuit

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: After a voyage, he hath strange places crammd

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: With observation, the which he vents

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: In mangled forms. O that I were a fool!

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: I am ambitious for a motley coat.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Thou shalt have one.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: It is my only suit;

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Provided that you weed your better judgments

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Of all opinion that grows rank in them

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: That I am wise. I must have liberty

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Withal, as large a charter as the wind,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: To blow on whom I please; for so fools have;

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And they that are most galled with my folly,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: They most must laugh. And why, sir, must they so?

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: The why is plain as way to parish church:

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: He that a fool doth very wisely hit

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Doth very foolishly, although he smart,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Not to seem senseless of the bob: if not,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: The wise mans folly is anatomized

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Even by the squandering glances of the fool.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Invest me in my motley; give me leave

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: To speak my mind, and I will through and through

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Cleanse the foul body of the infected world,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: If they will patiently receive my medicine.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Fie on thee! I can tell what thou wouldst do.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: What, for a counter, would I do but good?

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Most mischievous foul sin, in chiding sin:

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: For thou thyself hast been a libertine,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: As sensual as the brutish sting itself;

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: And all the embossed sores and headed evils,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: That thou with licence of free foot hast caught,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Wouldst thou disgorge into the general world.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Why, who cries out on pride,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: That can therein tax any private party?

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Doth it not flow as hugely as the sea,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Till that the weary very means do ebb?

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: What woman in the city do I name,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: When that I say the city-woman bears

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: The cost of princes on unworthy shoulders?

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Who can come in and say that I mean her,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: When such a one as she such is her neighbour?

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Or what is he of basest function

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: That says his bravery is not of my cost,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Thinking that I mean him, but therein suits

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: His folly to the mettle of my speech?

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: There then; how then? what then? Let me see wherein

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: My tongue hath wrongd him: if it do him right,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Then he hath wrongd himself; if he be free,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Why then my taxing like a wild-goose flies,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Unclaimd of any man. But who comes here?

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Enter ORLANDO, with his sword drawn

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Forbear, and eat no more.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Why, I have eat none yet.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Nor shalt not, till necessity be served.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Of what kind should this cock come of?

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Art thou thus boldend, man, by thy distress,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Or else a rude despiser of good manners,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: That in civility thou seemst so empty?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: You touchd my vein at first: the thorny point

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Of bare distress hath taen from me the show

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Of smooth civility: yet am I inland bred

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And know some nurture. But forbear, I say:

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: He dies that touches any of this fruit

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Till I and my affairs are answered.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: An you will not be answered with reason, I must die.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: What would you have? Your gentleness shall force

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: More than your force move us to gentleness.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I almost die for food; and let me have it.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Sit down and feed, and welcome to our table.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Speak you so gently? Pardon me, I pray you:

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I thought that all things had been savage here;

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And therefore put I on the countenance

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Of stern commandment. But whateer you are

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: That in this desert inaccessible,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Under the shade of melancholy boughs,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Lose and neglect the creeping hours of time

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: If ever you have lookd on better days,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: If ever been where bells have knolld to church,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: If ever sat at any good mans feast,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: If ever from your eyelids wiped a tear

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And know what tis to pity and be pitied,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Let gentleness my strong enforcement be:

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: In the which hope I blush, and hide my sword.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: True is it that we have seen better days,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: And have with holy bell been knolld to church

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: And sat at good mens feasts and wiped our eyes

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Of drops that sacred pity hath engenderd:

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: And therefore sit you down in gentleness

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: And take upon command what help we have

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: That to your wanting may be ministerd.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Then but forbear your food a little while,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Whiles, like a doe, I go to find my fawn

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And give it food. There is an old poor man,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Who after me hath many a weary step

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Limpd in pure love: till he be first sufficed,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Oppressd with two weak evils, age and hunger,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I will not touch a bit.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Go find him out,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: And we will nothing waste till you return.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I thank ye; and be blest for your good comfort!

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Thou seest we are not all alone unhappy:

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: This wide and universal theatre

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Presents more woeful pageants than the scene

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Wherein we play in.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: All the worlds a stage,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And all the men and women merely players:

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: They have their exits and their entrances;

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And one man in his time plays many parts,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: His acts being seven ages. At first the infant,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Mewling and puking in the nurses arms.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And then the whining school-boy, with his satchel

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And shining morning face, creeping like snail

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Unwillingly to school. And then the lover,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Sighing like furnace, with a woeful ballad

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Made to his mistress eyebrow. Then a soldier,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Full of strange oaths and bearded like the pard,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Jealous in honour, sudden and quick in quarrel,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Seeking the bubble reputation

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Even in the cannons mouth. And then the justice,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: In fair round belly with good capon lined,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: With eyes severe and beard of formal cut,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Full of wise saws and modern instances;

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And so he plays his part. The sixth age shifts

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Into the lean and slipperd pantaloon,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: With spectacles on nose and pouch on side,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: His youthful hose, well saved, a world too wide

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: For his shrunk shank; and his big manly voice,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Turning again toward childish treble, pipes

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And whistles in his sound. Last scene of all,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: That ends this strange eventful history,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Is second childishness and mere oblivion,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Sans teeth, sans eyes, sans taste, sans everything.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Re-enter ORLANDO, with ADAM

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Welcome. Set down your venerable burthen,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: And let him feed.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I thank you most for him.

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: So had you need:

speaker: ADAM
text_entry: I scarce can speak to thank you for myself.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Welcome; fall to: I will not trouble you

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: As yet, to question you about your fortunes.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Give us some music; and, good cousin, sing.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: SONG.

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Blow, blow, thou winter wind.

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Thou art not so unkind

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: As mans ingratitude;

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Thy tooth is not so keen,

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Because thou art not seen,

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Although thy breath be rude.

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Heigh-ho! sing, heigh-ho! unto the green holly:

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Most friendship is feigning, most loving mere folly:

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Then, heigh-ho, the holly!

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: This life is most jolly.

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Freeze, freeze, thou bitter sky,

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: That dost not bite so nigh

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: As benefits forgot:

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Though thou the waters warp,

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Thy sting is not so sharp

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: As friend rememberd not.

speaker: AMIENS
text_entry: Heigh-ho! sing,  and c.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: If that you were the good Sir Rowlands son,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: As you have whisperd faithfully you were,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: And as mine eye doth his effigies witness

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Most truly limnd and living in your face,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Be truly welcome hither: I am the duke

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: That loved your father: the residue of your fortune,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Go to my cave and tell me. Good old man,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Thou art right welcome as thy master is.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Support him by the arm. Give me your hand,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: And let me all your fortunes understand.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: ACT III

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: SCENE I. A room in the palace.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Enter DUKE FREDERICK, Lords, and OLIVER

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Not see him since? Sir, sir, that cannot be:

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: But were I not the better part made mercy,

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: I should not seek an absent argument

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Of my revenge, thou present. But look to it:

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Find out thy brother, wheresoeer he is;

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Seek him with candle; bring him dead or living

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Within this twelvemonth, or turn thou no more

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: To seek a living in our territory.

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Thy lands and all things that thou dost call thine

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Worth seizure do we seize into our hands,

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Till thou canst quit thee by thy brothers mouth

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Of what we think against thee.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: O that your highness knew my heart in this!

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: I never loved my brother in my life.

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: More villain thou. Well, push him out of doors;

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: And let my officers of such a nature

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Make an extent upon his house and lands:

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Do this expediently and turn him going.

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: SCENE II. The forest.

speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
text_entry: Enter ORLANDO, with a paper

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Hang there, my verse, in witness of my love:

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And thou, thrice-crowned queen of night, survey

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: With thy chaste eye, from thy pale sphere above,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Thy huntress name that my full life doth sway.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: O Rosalind! these trees shall be my books

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And in their barks my thoughts Ill character;

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: That every eye which in this forest looks

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Shall see thy virtue witnessd every where.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Run, run, Orlando; carve on every tree

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: The fair, the chaste and unexpressive she.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Enter CORIN and TOUCHSTONE

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: And how like you this shepherds life, Master Touchstone?

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Truly, shepherd, in respect of itself, it is a good

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: life, but in respect that it is a shepherds life,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: it is naught. In respect that it is solitary, I

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: like it very well; but in respect that it is

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: private, it is a very vile life. Now, in respect it

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: is in the fields, it pleaseth me well; but in

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: respect it is not in the court, it is tedious. As

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: is it a spare life, look you, it fits my humour well;

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: but as there is no more plenty in it, it goes much

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: against my stomach. Hast any philosophy in thee, shepherd?

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: No more but that I know the more one sickens the

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: worse at ease he is; and that he that wants money,

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: means and content is without three good friends;

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: that the property of rain is to wet and fire to

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: burn; that good pasture makes fat sheep, and that a

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: great cause of the night is lack of the sun; that

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: he that hath learned no wit by nature nor art may

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: complain of good breeding or comes of a very dull kindred.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Such a one is a natural philosopher. Wast ever in

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: court, shepherd?

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: No, truly.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Then thou art damned.

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Nay, I hope.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Truly, thou art damned like an ill-roasted egg, all

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: on one side.

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: For not being at court? Your reason.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Why, if thou never wast at court, thou never sawest

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: good manners; if thou never sawest good manners,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: then thy manners must be wicked; and wickedness is

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: sin, and sin is damnation. Thou art in a parlous

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: state, shepherd.

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Not a whit, Touchstone: those that are good manners

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: at the court are as ridiculous in the country as the

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: behavior of the country is most mockable at the

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: court. You told me you salute not at the court, but

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: you kiss your hands: that courtesy would be

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: uncleanly, if courtiers were shepherds.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Instance, briefly; come, instance.

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Why, we are still handling our ewes, and their

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: fells, you know, are greasy.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Why, do not your courtiers hands sweat? and is not

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: the grease of a mutton as wholesome as the sweat of

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: a man? Shallow, shallow. A better instance, I say; come.

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Besides, our hands are hard.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Your lips will feel them the sooner. Shallow again.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: A more sounder instance, come.

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: And they are often tarred over with the surgery of

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: our sheep: and would you have us kiss tar? The

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: courtiers hands are perfumed with civet.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Most shallow man! thou worms-meat, in respect of a

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: good piece of flesh indeed! Learn of the wise, and

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: perpend: civet is of a baser birth than tar, the

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: very uncleanly flux of a cat. Mend the instance, shepherd.

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: You have too courtly a wit for me: Ill rest.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Wilt thou rest damned? God help thee, shallow man!

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: God make incision in thee! thou art raw.

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Sir, I am a true labourer: I earn that I eat, get

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: that I wear, owe no man hate, envy no mans

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: happiness, glad of other mens good, content with my

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: harm, and the greatest of my pride is to see my ewes

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: graze and my lambs suck.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: That is another simple sin in you, to bring the ewes

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: and the rams together and to offer to get your

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: living by the copulation of cattle; to be bawd to a

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: bell-wether, and to betray a she-lamb of a

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: twelvemonth to a crooked-pated, old, cuckoldly ram,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: out of all reasonable match. If thou beest not

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: damned for this, the devil himself will have no

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: shepherds; I cannot see else how thou shouldst

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: scape.

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Here comes young Master Ganymede, my new mistresss brother.

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Enter ROSALIND, with a paper, reading

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: From the east to western Ind,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: No jewel is like Rosalind.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Her worth, being mounted on the wind,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Through all the world bears Rosalind.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: All the pictures fairest lined

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Are but black to Rosalind.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Let no fair be kept in mind

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: But the fair of Rosalind.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Ill rhyme you so eight years together, dinners and

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: suppers and sleeping-hours excepted: it is the

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: right butter-womens rank to market.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Out, fool!

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: For a taste:

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: If a hart do lack a hind,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Let him seek out Rosalind.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: If the cat will after kind,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: So be sure will Rosalind.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Winter garments must be lined,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: So must slender Rosalind.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: They that reap must sheaf and bind;

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Then to cart with Rosalind.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Sweetest nut hath sourest rind,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Such a nut is Rosalind.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: He that sweetest rose will find

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Must find loves prick and Rosalind.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: This is the very false gallop of verses: why do you

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: infect yourself with them?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Peace, you dull fool! I found them on a tree.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Truly, the tree yields bad fruit.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Ill graff it with you, and then I shall graff it

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: with a medlar: then it will be the earliest fruit

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: i the country; for youll be rotten ere you be half

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: ripe, and thats the right virtue of the medlar.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: You have said; but whether wisely or no, let the

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: forest judge.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Enter CELIA, with a writing

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Peace! Here comes my sister, reading: stand aside.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: [Reads]

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Why should this a desert be?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: For it is unpeopled? No:

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Tongues Ill hang on every tree,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: That shall civil sayings show:

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Some, how brief the life of man

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Runs his erring pilgrimage,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: That the stretching of a span

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Buckles in his sum of age;

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Some, of violated vows

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Twixt the souls of friend and friend:

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: But upon the fairest boughs,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Or at every sentence end,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Will I Rosalinda write,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Teaching all that read to know

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: The quintessence of every sprite

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Heaven would in little show.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Therefore Heaven Nature charged

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: That one body should be filld

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: With all graces wide-enlarged:

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Nature presently distilld

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Helens cheek, but not her heart,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Cleopatras majesty,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Atalantas better part,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Sad Lucretias modesty.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Thus Rosalind of many parts

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: By heavenly synod was devised,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Of many faces, eyes and hearts,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: To have the touches dearest prized.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Heaven would that she these gifts should have,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: And I to live and die her slave.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: O most gentle pulpiter! what tedious homily of love

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: have you wearied your parishioners withal, and never

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: cried Have patience, good people!

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: How now! back, friends! Shepherd, go off a little.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Go with him, sirrah.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Come, shepherd, let us make an honourable retreat;

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: though not with bag and baggage, yet with scrip and scrippage.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Exeunt CORIN and TOUCHSTONE

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Didst thou hear these verses?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: O, yes, I heard them all, and more too; for some of

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: them had in them more feet than the verses would bear.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Thats no matter: the feet might bear the verses.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Ay, but the feet were lame and could not bear

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: themselves without the verse and therefore stood

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: lamely in the verse.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: But didst thou hear without wondering how thy name

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: should be hanged and carved upon these trees?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I was seven of the nine days out of the wonder

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: before you came; for look here what I found on a

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: palm-tree. I was never so be-rhymed since

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Pythagoras time, that I was an Irish rat, which I

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: can hardly remember.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Trow you who hath done this?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Is it a man?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: And a chain, that you once wore, about his neck.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Change you colour?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I prithee, who?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: O Lord, Lord! it is a hard matter for friends to

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: meet; but mountains may be removed with earthquakes

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: and so encounter.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Nay, but who is it?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Is it possible?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Nay, I prithee now with most petitionary vehemence,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: tell me who it is.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: O wonderful, wonderful, and most wonderful

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: wonderful! and yet again wonderful, and after that,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: out of all hooping!

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Good my complexion! dost thou think, though I am

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: caparisoned like a man, I have a doublet and hose in

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: my disposition? One inch of delay more is a

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: South-sea of discovery; I prithee, tell me who is it

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: quickly, and speak apace. I would thou couldst

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: stammer, that thou mightst pour this concealed man

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: out of thy mouth, as wine comes out of a narrow-

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: mouthed bottle, either too much at once, or none at

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: all. I prithee, take the cork out of thy mouth that

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: may drink thy tidings.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: So you may put a man in your belly.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Is he of Gods making? What manner of man? Is his

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: head worth a hat, or his chin worth a beard?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Nay, he hath but a little beard.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Why, God will send more, if the man will be

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: thankful: let me stay the growth of his beard, if

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: thou delay me not the knowledge of his chin.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: It is young Orlando, that tripped up the wrestlers

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: heels and your heart both in an instant.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Nay, but the devil take mocking: speak, sad brow and

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: true maid.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: I faith, coz, tis he.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Orlando?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Orlando.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Alas the day! what shall I do with my doublet and

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: hose? What did he when thou sawest him? What said

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: he? How looked he? Wherein went he? What makes

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: him here? Did he ask for me? Where remains he?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: How parted he with thee? and when shalt thou see

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: him again? Answer me in one word.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: You must borrow me Gargantuas mouth first: tis a

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: word too great for any mouth of this ages size. To

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: say ay and no to these particulars is more than to

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: answer in a catechism.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: But doth he know that I am in this forest and in

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: mans apparel? Looks he as freshly as he did the

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: day he wrestled?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: It is as easy to count atomies as to resolve the

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: propositions of a lover; but take a taste of my

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: finding him, and relish it with good observance.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: I found him under a tree, like a dropped acorn.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: It may well be called Joves tree, when it drops

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: forth such fruit.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Give me audience, good madam.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Proceed.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: There lay he, stretched along, like a wounded knight.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Though it be pity to see such a sight, it well

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: becomes the ground.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Cry holla to thy tongue, I prithee; it curvets

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: unseasonably. He was furnished like a hunter.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: O, ominous! he comes to kill my heart.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: I would sing my song without a burden: thou bringest

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: me out of tune.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Do you not know I am a woman? when I think, I must

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: speak. Sweet, say on.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: You bring me out. Soft! comes he not here?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Enter ORLANDO and JAQUES

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Tis he: slink by, and note him.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: I thank you for your company; but, good faith, I had

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: as lief have been myself alone.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And so had I; but yet, for fashion sake, I thank you

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: too for your society.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: God be wi you: lets meet as little as we can.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I do desire we may be better strangers.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: I pray you, mar no more trees with writing

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: love-songs in their barks.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I pray you, mar no more of my verses with reading

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: them ill-favouredly.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Rosalind is your loves name?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Yes, just.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: I do not like her name.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: There was no thought of pleasing you when she was

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: christened.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: What stature is she of?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Just as high as my heart.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: You are full of pretty answers. Have you not been

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: acquainted with goldsmiths wives, and conned them

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: out of rings?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Not so; but I answer you right painted cloth, from

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: whence you have studied your questions.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: You have a nimble wit: I think twas made of

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Atalantas heels. Will you sit down with me? and

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: we two will rail against our mistress the world and

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: all our misery.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I will chide no breather in the world but myself,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: against whom I know most faults.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: The worst fault you have is to be in love.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Tis a fault I will not change for your best virtue.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I am weary of you.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: By my troth, I was seeking for a fool when I found

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: you.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: He is drowned in the brook: look but in, and you

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: shall see him.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: There I shall see mine own figure.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Which I take to be either a fool or a cipher.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Ill tarry no longer with you: farewell, good

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Signior Love.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I am glad of your departure: adieu, good Monsieur

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Melancholy.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Exit JAQUES

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: [Aside to CELIA]  I will speak to him, like a saucy

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: lackey and under that habit play the knave with him.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Do you hear, forester?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Very well: what would you?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I pray you, what ist oclock?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: You should ask me what time o day: theres no clock

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: in the forest.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Then there is no true lover in the forest; else

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: sighing every minute and groaning every hour would

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: detect the lazy foot of Time as well as a clock.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And why not the swift foot of Time? had not that

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: been as proper?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: By no means, sir: Time travels in divers paces with

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: divers persons. Ill tell you who Time ambles

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: withal, who Time trots withal, who Time gallops

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: withal and who he stands still withal.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I prithee, who doth he trot withal?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Marry, he trots hard with a young maid between the

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: contract of her marriage and the day it is

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: solemnized: if the interim be but a sennight,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Times pace is so hard that it seems the length of

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: seven year.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Who ambles Time withal?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: With a priest that lacks Latin and a rich man that

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: hath not the gout, for the one sleeps easily because

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: he cannot study, and the other lives merrily because

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: he feels no pain, the one lacking the burden of lean

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: and wasteful learning, the other knowing no burden

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: of heavy tedious penury; these Time ambles withal.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Who doth he gallop withal?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: With a thief to the gallows, for though he go as

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: softly as foot can fall, he thinks himself too soon there.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Who stays it still withal?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: With lawyers in the vacation, for they sleep between

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: term and term and then they perceive not how Time moves.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Where dwell you, pretty youth?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: With this shepherdess, my sister; here in the

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: skirts of the forest, like fringe upon a petticoat.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Are you native of this place?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: As the cony that you see dwell where she is kindled.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Your accent is something finer than you could

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: purchase in so removed a dwelling.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I have been told so of many: but indeed an old

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: religious uncle of mine taught me to speak, who was

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: in his youth an inland man; one that knew courtship

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: too well, for there he fell in love. I have heard

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: him read many lectures against it, and I thank God

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I am not a woman, to be touched with so many

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: giddy offences as he hath generally taxed their

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: whole sex withal.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Can you remember any of the principal evils that he

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: laid to the charge of women?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: There were none principal; they were all like one

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: another as half-pence are, every one fault seeming

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: monstrous till his fellow fault came to match it.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I prithee, recount some of them.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: No, I will not cast away my physic but on those that

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: are sick. There is a man haunts the forest, that

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: abuses our young plants with carving Rosalind on

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: their barks; hangs odes upon hawthorns and elegies

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: on brambles, all, forsooth, deifying the name of

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Rosalind: if I could meet that fancy-monger I would

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: give him some good counsel, for he seems to have the

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: quotidian of love upon him.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I am he that is so love-shaked: I pray you tell me

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: your remedy.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: There is none of my uncles marks upon you: he

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: taught me how to know a man in love; in which cage

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: of rushes I am sure you are not prisoner.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: What were his marks?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: A lean cheek, which you have not, a blue eye and

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: sunken, which you have not, an unquestionable

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: spirit, which you have not, a beard neglected,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: which you have not; but I pardon you for that, for

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: simply your having in beard is a younger brothers

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: revenue: then your hose should be ungartered, your

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: bonnet unbanded, your sleeve unbuttoned, your shoe

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: untied and every thing about you demonstrating a

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: careless desolation; but you are no such man; you

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: are rather point-device in your accoutrements as

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: loving yourself than seeming the lover of any other.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Fair youth, I would I could make thee believe I love.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Me believe it! you may as soon make her that you

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: love believe it; which, I warrant, she is apter to

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: do than to confess she does: that is one of the

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: points in the which women still give the lie to

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: their consciences. But, in good sooth, are you he

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: that hangs the verses on the trees, wherein Rosalind

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: is so admired?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I swear to thee, youth, by the white hand of

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Rosalind, I am that he, that unfortunate he.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: But are you so much in love as your rhymes speak?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Neither rhyme nor reason can express how much.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Love is merely a madness, and, I tell you, deserves

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: as well a dark house and a whip as madmen do: and

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: the reason why they are not so punished and cured

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: is, that the lunacy is so ordinary that the whippers

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: are in love too. Yet I profess curing it by counsel.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Did you ever cure any so?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Yes, one, and in this manner. He was to imagine me

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: his love, his mistress; and I set him every day to

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: woo me: at which time would I, being but a moonish

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: youth, grieve, be effeminate, changeable, longing

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: and liking, proud, fantastical, apish, shallow,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: inconstant, full of tears, full of smiles, for every

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: passion something and for no passion truly any

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: thing, as boys and women are for the most part

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: cattle of this colour; would now like him, now loathe

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: him; then entertain him, then forswear him; now weep

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: for him, then spit at him; that I drave my suitor

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: from his mad humour of love to a living humour of

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: madness; which was, to forswear the full stream of

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: the world, and to live in a nook merely monastic.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And thus I cured him; and this way will I take upon

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: me to wash your liver as clean as a sound sheeps

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: heart, that there shall not be one spot of love int.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I would not be cured, youth.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I would cure you, if you would but call me Rosalind

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: and come every day to my cote and woo me.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Now, by the faith of my love, I will: tell me

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: where it is.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Go with me to it and Ill show it you and by the way

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: you shall tell me where in the forest you live.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Will you go?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: With all my heart, good youth.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Nay you must call me Rosalind. Come, sister, will you go?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: SCENE III. The forest.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Enter TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY; JAQUES behind

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Come apace, good Audrey: I will fetch up your

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: goats, Audrey. And how, Audrey? am I the man yet?

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: doth my simple feature content you?

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: Your features! Lord warrant us! what features!

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: I am here with thee and thy goats, as the most

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: capricious poet, honest Ovid, was among the Goths.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: [Aside]  O knowledge ill-inhabited, worse than Jove

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: in a thatched house!

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: When a mans verses cannot be understood, nor a

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: mans good wit seconded with the forward child

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Understanding, it strikes a man more dead than a

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: great reckoning in a little room. Truly, I would

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: the gods had made thee poetical.

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: I do not know what poetical is: is it honest in

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: deed and word? is it a true thing?

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: No, truly; for the truest poetry is the most

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: feigning; and lovers are given to poetry, and what

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: they swear in poetry may be said as lovers they do feign.

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: Do you wish then that the gods had made me poetical?

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: I do, truly; for thou swearest to me thou art

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: honest: now, if thou wert a poet, I might have some

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: hope thou didst feign.

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: Would you not have me honest?

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: No, truly, unless thou wert hard-favoured; for

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: honesty coupled to beauty is to have honey a sauce to sugar.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: [Aside]  A material fool!

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: Well, I am not fair; and therefore I pray the gods

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: make me honest.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Truly, and to cast away honesty upon a foul slut

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: were to put good meat into an unclean dish.

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: I am not a slut, though I thank the gods I am foul.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Well, praised be the gods for thy foulness!

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: sluttishness may come hereafter. But be it as it may

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: be, I will marry thee, and to that end I have been

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: with Sir Oliver Martext, the vicar of the next

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: village, who hath promised to meet me in this place

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: of the forest and to couple us.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: [Aside]  I would fain see this meeting.

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: Well, the gods give us joy!

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Amen. A man may, if he were of a fearful heart,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: stagger in this attempt; for here we have no temple

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: but the wood, no assembly but horn-beasts. But what

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: though? C ourage! As horns are odious, they are

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: necessary. It is said, many a man knows no end of

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: his goods: right; many a man has good horns, and

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: knows no end of them. Well, that is the dowry of

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: his wife; tis none of his own getting. Horns?

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Even so. Poor men alone? No, no; the noblest deer

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: hath them as huge as the rascal. Is the single man

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: therefore blessed? No: as a walled town is more

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: worthier than a village, so is the forehead of a

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: married man more honourable than the bare brow of a

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: bachelor; and by how much defence is better than no

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: skill, by so much is a horn more precious than to

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: want. Here comes Sir Oliver.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Enter SIR OLIVER MARTEXT

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Sir Oliver Martext, you are well met: will you

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: dispatch us here under this tree, or shall we go

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: with you to your chapel?

speaker: SIR OLIVER MARTEXT
text_entry: Is there none here to give the woman?

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: I will not take her on gift of any man.

speaker: SIR OLIVER MARTEXT
text_entry: Truly, she must be given, or the marriage is not lawful.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: [Advancing]

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Proceed, proceedIll give her.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Good even, good Master What-ye-callt: how do you,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: sir? You are very well met: God ild you for your

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: last company: I am very glad to see you: even a

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: toy in hand here, sir: nay, pray be covered.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Will you be married, motley?

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: As the ox hath his bow, sir, the horse his curb and

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: the falcon her bells, so man hath his desires; and

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: as pigeons bill, so wedlock would be nibbling.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And will you, being a man of your breeding, be

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: married under a bush like a beggar? Get you to

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: church, and have a good priest that can tell you

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: what marriage is: this fellow will but join you

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: together as they join wainscot; then one of you will

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: prove a shrunk panel and, like green timber, warp, warp.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: [Aside]  I am not in the mind but I were better to be

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: married of him than of another: for he is not like

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: to marry me well; and not being well married, it

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: will be a good excuse for me hereafter to leave my wife.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Go thou with me, and let me counsel thee.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Come, sweet Audrey:

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: We must be married, or we must live in bawdry.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Farewell, good Master Oliver: not,--

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: O sweet Oliver,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: O brave Oliver,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Leave me not behind thee: but,--

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Wind away,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Begone, I say,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: I will not to wedding with thee.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Exeunt JAQUES, TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY

speaker: SIR OLIVER MARTEXT
text_entry: Tis no matter: neer a fantastical knave of them

speaker: SIR OLIVER MARTEXT
text_entry: all shall flout me out of my calling.

speaker: SIR OLIVER MARTEXT
text_entry: Exit

speaker: SIR OLIVER MARTEXT
text_entry: SCENE IV. The forest.

speaker: SIR OLIVER MARTEXT
text_entry: Enter ROSALIND and CELIA

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Never talk to me; I will weep.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Do, I prithee; but yet have the grace to consider

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: that tears do not become a man.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: But have I not cause to weep?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: As good cause as one would desire; therefore weep.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: His very hair is of the dissembling colour.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Something browner than Judass marry, his kisses are

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Judass own children.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I faith, his hair is of a good colour.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: An excellent colour: your chestnut was ever the only colour.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And his kissing is as full of sanctity as the touch

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: of holy bread.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: He hath bought a pair of cast lips of Diana: a nun

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: of winters sisterhood kisses not more religiously;

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: the very ice of chastity is in them.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: But why did he swear he would come this morning, and

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: comes not?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Nay, certainly, there is no truth in him.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Do you think so?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Yes; I think he is not a pick-purse nor a

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: horse-stealer, but for his verity in love, I do

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: think him as concave as a covered goblet or a

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: worm-eaten nut.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Not true in love?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Yes, when he is in; but I think he is not in.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: You have heard him swear downright he was.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Was is not is: besides, the oath of a lover is

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: no stronger than the word of a tapster; they are

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: both the confirmer of false reckonings. He attends

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: here in the forest on the duke your father.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I met the duke yesterday and had much question with

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: him: he asked me of what parentage I was; I told

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: him, of as good as he; so he laughed and let me go.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: But what talk we of fathers, when there is such a

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: man as Orlando?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: O, thats a brave man! he writes brave verses,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: speaks brave words, swears brave oaths and breaks

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: them bravely, quite traverse, athwart the heart of

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: his lover; as a puisny tilter, that spurs his horse

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: but on one side, breaks his staff like a noble

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: goose: but alls brave that youth mounts and folly

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: guides. Who comes here?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Enter CORIN

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Mistress and master, you have oft inquired

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: After the shepherd that complaind of love,

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Who you saw sitting by me on the turf,

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Praising the proud disdainful shepherdess

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: That was his mistress.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Well, and what of him?

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: If you will see a pageant truly playd,

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Between the pale complexion of true love

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: And the red glow of scorn and proud disdain,

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Go hence a little and I shall conduct you,

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: If you will mark it.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: O, come, let us remove:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: The sight of lovers feedeth those in love.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Bring us to this sight, and you shall say

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Ill prove a busy actor in their play.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: SCENE V. Another part of the forest.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Enter SILVIUS and PHEBE

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Sweet Phebe, do not scorn me; do not, Phebe;

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Say that you love me not, but say not so

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: In bitterness. The common executioner,

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Whose heart the accustomd sight of death makes hard,

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Falls not the axe upon the humbled neck

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: But first begs pardon: will you sterner be

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Than he that dies and lives by bloody drops?

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Enter ROSALIND, CELIA, and CORIN, behind

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: I would not be thy executioner:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: I fly thee, for I would not injure thee.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Thou tellst me there is murder in mine eye:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Tis pretty, sure, and very probable,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: That eyes, that are the frailst and softest things,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Who shut their coward gates on atomies,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Should be calld tyrants, butchers, murderers!

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Now I do frown on thee with all my heart;

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: And if mine eyes can wound, now let them kill thee:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Now counterfeit to swoon; why now fall down;

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Or if thou canst not, O, for shame, for shame,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Lie not, to say mine eyes are murderers!

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Now show the wound mine eye hath made in thee:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Scratch thee but with a pin, and there remains

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Some scar of it; lean but upon a rush,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: The cicatrice and capable impressure

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Thy palm some moment keeps; but now mine eyes,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Which I have darted at thee, hurt thee not,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Nor, I am sure, there is no force in eyes

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: That can do hurt.

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: O dear Phebe,

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: If ever,--as that ever may be near,--

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: You meet in some fresh cheek the power of fancy,

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Then shall you know the wounds invisible

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: That loves keen arrows make.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: But till that time

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Come not thou near me: and when that time comes,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Afflict me with thy mocks, pity me not;

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: As till that time I shall not pity thee.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And why, I pray you? Who might be your mother,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: That you insult, exult, and all at once,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Over the wretched? What though you have no beauty,--

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: As, by my faith, I see no more in you

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Than without candle may go dark to bed--

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Must you be therefore proud and pitiless?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Why, what means this? Why do you look on me?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I see no more in you than in the ordinary

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Of natures sale-work. Ods my little life,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I think she means to tangle my eyes too!

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: No, faith, proud mistress, hope not after it:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Tis not your inky brows, your black silk hair,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Your bugle eyeballs, nor your cheek of cream,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: That can entame my spirits to your worship.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: You foolish shepherd, wherefore do you follow her,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Like foggy south puffing with wind and rain?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: You are a thousand times a properer man

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Than she a woman: tis such fools as you

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: That makes the world full of ill-favourd children:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Tis not her glass, but you, that flatters her;

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And out of you she sees herself more proper

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Than any of her lineaments can show her.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: But, mistress, know yourself: down on your knees,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And thank heaven, fasting, for a good mans love:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: For I must tell you friendly in your ear,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Sell when you can: you are not for all markets:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Cry the man mercy; love him; take his offer:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Foul is most foul, being foul to be a scoffer.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: So take her to thee, shepherd: fare you well.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Sweet youth, I pray you, chide a year together:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: I had rather hear you chide than this man woo.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Hes fallen in love with your foulness and shell

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: fall in love with my anger. If it be so, as fast as

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: she answers thee with frowning looks, Ill sauce her

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: with bitter words. Why look you so upon me?

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: For no ill will I bear you.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I pray you, do not fall in love with me,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: For I am falser than vows made in wine:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Besides, I like you not. If you will know my house,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Tis at the tuft of olives here hard by.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Will you go, sister? Shepherd, ply her hard.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Come, sister. Shepherdess, look on him better,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And be not proud: though all the world could see,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: None could be so abused in sight as he.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Come, to our flock.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Exeunt ROSALIND, CELIA and CORIN

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Dead Shepherd, now I find thy saw of might,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Who ever loved that loved not at first sight?

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Sweet Phebe,--

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Ha, what sayst thou, Silvius?

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Sweet Phebe, pity me.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Why, I am sorry for thee, gentle Silvius.

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Wherever sorrow is, relief would be:

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: If you do sorrow at my grief in love,

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: By giving love your sorrow and my grief

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Were both extermined.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Thou hast my love: is not that neighbourly?

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: I would have you.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Why, that were covetousness.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Silvius, the time was that I hated thee,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: And yet it is not that I bear thee love;

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: But since that thou canst talk of love so well,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Thy company, which erst was irksome to me,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: I will endure, and Ill employ thee too:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: But do not look for further recompense

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Than thine own gladness that thou art employd.

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: So holy and so perfect is my love,

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: And I in such a poverty of grace,

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: That I shall think it a most plenteous crop

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: To glean the broken ears after the man

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: That the main harvest reaps: loose now and then

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: A scatterd smile, and that Ill live upon.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Knowst now the youth that spoke to me erewhile?

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Not very well, but I have met him oft;

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: And he hath bought the cottage and the bounds

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: That the old carlot once was master of.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Think not I love him, though I ask for him:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Tis but a peevish boy; yet he talks well;

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: But what care I for words? yet words do well

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: When he that speaks them pleases those that hear.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: It is a pretty youth: not very pretty:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: But, sure, hes proud, and yet his pride becomes him:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Hell make a proper man: the best thing in him

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Is his complexion; and faster than his tongue

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Did make offence his eye did heal it up.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: He is not very tall; yet for his years hes tall:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: His leg is but so so; and yet tis well:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: There was a pretty redness in his lip,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: A little riper and more lusty red

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Than that mixd in his cheek; twas just the difference

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Between the constant red and mingled damask.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: There be some women, Silvius, had they markd him

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: In parcels as I did, would have gone near

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: To fall in love with him; but, for my part,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: I love him not nor hate him not; and yet

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: I have more cause to hate him than to love him:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: For what had he to do to chide at me?

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: He said mine eyes were black and my hair black:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: And, now I am rememberd, scornd at me:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: I marvel why I answerd not again:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: But thats all one; omittance is no quittance.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Ill write to him a very taunting letter,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: And thou shalt bear it: wilt thou, Silvius?

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Phebe, with all my heart.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Ill write it straight;

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: The matters in my head and in my heart:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: I will be bitter with him and passing short.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Go with me, Silvius.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: ACT IV

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: SCENE I. The forest.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Enter ROSALIND, CELIA, and JAQUES

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: I prithee, pretty youth, let me be better acquainted

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: with thee.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: They say you are a melancholy fellow.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: I am so; I do love it better than laughing.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Those that are in extremity of either are abominable

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: fellows and betray themselves to every modern

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: censure worse than drunkards.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Why, tis good to be sad and say nothing.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Why then, tis good to be a post.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: I have neither the scholars melancholy, which is

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: emulation, nor the musicians, which is fantastical,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: nor the courtiers, which is proud, nor the

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: soldiers, which is ambitious, nor the lawyers,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: which is politic, nor the ladys, which is nice, nor

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: the lovers, which is all these: but it is a

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: melancholy of mine own, compounded of many simples,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: extracted from many objects, and indeed the sundrys

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: contemplation of my travels, in which my often

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: rumination wraps me m a most humorous sadness.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: A traveller! By my faith, you have great reason to

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: be sad: I fear you have sold your own lands to see

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: other mens; then, to have seen much and to have

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: nothing, is to have rich eyes and poor hands.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Yes, I have gained my experience.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And your experience makes you sad: I had rather have

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: a fool to make me merry than experience to make me

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: sad; and to travel for it too!

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Enter ORLANDO

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Good day and happiness, dear Rosalind!

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Nay, then, God be wi you, an you talk in blank verse.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Exit

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Farewell, Monsieur Traveller: look you lisp and

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: wear strange suits, disable all the benefits of your

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: own country, be out of love with your nativity and

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: almost chide God for making you that countenance you

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: are, or I will scarce think you have swam in a

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: gondola. Why, how now, Orlando! where have you been

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: all this while? You a lover! An you serve me such

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: another trick, never come in my sight more.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: My fair Rosalind, I come within an hour of my promise.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Break an hours promise in love! He that will

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: divide a minute into a thousand parts and break but

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: a part of the thousandth part of a minute in the

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: affairs of love, it may be said of him that Cupid

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: hath clapped him o the shoulder, but Ill warrant

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: him heart-whole.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Pardon me, dear Rosalind.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Nay, an you be so tardy, come no more in my sight: I

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: had as lief be wooed of a snail.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Of a snail?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Ay, of a snail; for though he comes slowly, he

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: carries his house on his head; a better jointure,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I think, than you make a woman: besides he brings

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: his destiny with him.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Whats that?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Why, horns, which such as you are fain to be

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: beholding to your wives for: but he comes armed in

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: his fortune and prevents the slander of his wife.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Virtue is no horn-maker; and my Rosalind is virtuous.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And I am your Rosalind.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: It pleases him to call you so; but he hath a

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Rosalind of a better leer than you.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Come, woo me, woo me, for now I am in a holiday

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: humour and like enough to consent. What would you

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: say to me now, an I were your very very Rosalind?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I would kiss before I spoke.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Nay, you were better speak first, and when you were

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: gravelled for lack of matter, you might take

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: occasion to kiss. Very good orators, when they are

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: out, they will spit; and for lovers lacking--God

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: warn us!--matter, the cleanliest shift is to kiss.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: How if the kiss be denied?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Then she puts you to entreaty, and there begins new matter.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Who could be out, being before his beloved mistress?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Marry, that should you, if I were your mistress, or

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I should think my honesty ranker than my wit.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: What, of my suit?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Not out of your apparel, and yet out of your suit.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Am not I your Rosalind?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I take some joy to say you are, because I would be

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: talking of her.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Well in her person I say I will not have you.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Then in mine own person I die.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: No, faith, die by attorney. The poor world is

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: almost six thousand years old, and in all this time

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: there was not any man died in his own person,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: videlicit, in a love-cause. Troilus had his brains

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: dashed out with a Grecian club; yet he did what he

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: could to die before, and he is one of the patterns

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: of love. Leander, he would have lived many a fair

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: year, though Hero had turned nun, if it had not been

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: for a hot midsummer night; for, good youth, he went

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: but forth to wash him in the Hellespont and being

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: taken with the cramp was drowned and the foolish

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: coroners of that age found it was Hero of Sestos.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: But these are all lies: men have died from time to

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: time and worms have eaten them, but not for love.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I would not have my right Rosalind of this mind,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: for, I protest, her frown might kill me.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: By this hand, it will not kill a fly. But come, now

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I will be your Rosalind in a more coming-on

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: disposition, and ask me what you will. I will grant

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: it.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Then love me, Rosalind.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Yes, faith, will I, Fridays and Saturdays and all.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And wilt thou have me?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Ay, and twenty such.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: What sayest thou?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Are you not good?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I hope so.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Why then, can one desire too much of a good thing?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Come, sister, you shall be the priest and marry us.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Give me your hand, Orlando. What do you say, sister?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Pray thee, marry us.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: I cannot say the words.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: You must begin, Will you, Orlando--
