speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Go to. Will you, Orlando, have to wife this Rosalind?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I will.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Ay, but when?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Why now; as fast as she can marry us.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Then you must say I take thee, Rosalind, for wife.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I take thee, Rosalind, for wife.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I might ask you for your commission; but I do take

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: thee, Orlando, for my husband: theres a girl goes

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: before the priest; and certainly a womans thought

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: runs before her actions.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: So do all thoughts; they are winged.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Now tell me how long you would have her after you

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: have possessed her.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: For ever and a day.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Say a day, without the ever. No, no, Orlando;

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: men are April when they woo, December when they wed:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: maids are May when they are maids, but the sky

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: changes when they are wives. I will be more jealous

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: of thee than a Barbary cock-pigeon over his hen,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: more clamorous than a parrot against rain, more

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: new-fangled than an ape, more giddy in my desires

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: than a monkey: I will weep for nothing, like Diana

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: in the fountain, and I will do that when you are

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: disposed to be merry; I will laugh like a hyen, and

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: that when thou art inclined to sleep.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: But will my Rosalind do so?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: By my life, she will do as I do.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: O, but she is wise.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Or else she could not have the wit to do this: the

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: wiser, the waywarder: make the doors upon a womans

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: wit and it will out at the casement; shut that and

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: twill out at the key-hole; stop that, twill fly

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: with the smoke out at the chimney.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: A man that had a wife with such a wit, he might say

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Wit, whither wilt?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Nay, you might keep that cheque for it till you met

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: your wifes wit going to your neighbours bed.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And what wit could wit have to excuse that?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Marry, to say she came to seek you there. You shall

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: never take her without her answer, unless you take

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: her without her tongue. O, that woman that cannot

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: make her fault her husbands occasion, let her

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: never nurse her child herself, for she will breed

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: it like a fool!

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: For these two hours, Rosalind, I will leave thee.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Alas! dear love, I cannot lack thee two hours.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I must attend the duke at dinner: by two oclock I

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: will be with thee again.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Ay, go your ways, go your ways; I knew what you

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: would prove: my friends told me as much, and I

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: thought no less: that flattering tongue of yours

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: won me: tis but one cast away, and so, come,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: death! Two oclock is your hour?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Ay, sweet Rosalind.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: By my troth, and in good earnest, and so God mend

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: me, and by all pretty oaths that are not dangerous,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: if you break one jot of your promise or come one

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: minute behind your hour, I will think you the most

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: pathetical break-promise and the most hollow lover

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: and the most unworthy of her you call Rosalind that

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: may be chosen out of the gross band of the

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: unfaithful: therefore beware my censure and keep

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: your promise.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: With no less religion than if thou wert indeed my

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Rosalind: so adieu.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Well, Time is the old justice that examines all such

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: offenders, and let Time try: adieu.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Exit ORLANDO

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: You have simply misused our sex in your love-prate:

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: we must have your doublet and hose plucked over your

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: head, and show the world what the bird hath done to

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: her own nest.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: O coz, coz, coz, my pretty little coz, that thou

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: didst know how many fathom deep I am in love! But

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: it cannot be sounded: my affection hath an unknown

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: bottom, like the bay of Portugal.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Or rather, bottomless, that as fast as you pour

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: affection in, it runs out.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: No, that same wicked bastard of Venus that was begot

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: of thought, conceived of spleen and born of madness,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: that blind rascally boy that abuses every ones eyes

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: because his own are out, let him be judge how deep I

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: am in love. Ill tell thee, Aliena, I cannot be out

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: of the sight of Orlando: Ill go find a shadow and

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: sigh till he come.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: And Ill sleep.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: SCENE II. The forest.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Enter JAQUES, Lords, and Foresters

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Which is he that killed the deer?

speaker: A Lord
text_entry: Sir, it was I.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Lets present him to the duke, like a Roman

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: conqueror; and it would do well to set the deers

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: horns upon his head, for a branch of victory. Have

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: you no song, forester, for this purpose?

speaker: Forester
text_entry: Yes, sir.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Sing it: tis no matter how it be in tune, so it

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: make noise enough.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: SONG.

speaker: Forester
text_entry: What shall he have that killd the deer?

speaker: Forester
text_entry: His leather skin and horns to wear.

speaker: Forester
text_entry: Then sing him home;

speaker: Forester
text_entry: The rest shall bear this burden

speaker: Forester
text_entry: Take thou no scorn to wear the horn;

speaker: Forester
text_entry: It was a crest ere thou wast born:

speaker: Forester
text_entry: Thy fathers father wore it,

speaker: Forester
text_entry: And thy father bore it:

speaker: Forester
text_entry: The horn, the horn, the lusty horn

speaker: Forester
text_entry: Is not a thing to laugh to scorn.

speaker: Forester
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: Forester
text_entry: SCENE III. The forest.

speaker: Forester
text_entry: Enter ROSALIND and CELIA

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: How say you now? Is it not past two oclock? and

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: here much Orlando!

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: I warrant you, with pure love and troubled brain, he

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: hath taen his bow and arrows and is gone forth to

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: sleep. Look, who comes here.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Enter SILVIUS

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: My errand is to you, fair youth;

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: My gentle Phebe bid me give you this:

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: I know not the contents; but, as I guess

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: By the stern brow and waspish action

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Which she did use as she was writing of it,

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: It bears an angry tenor: pardon me:

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: I am but as a guiltless messenger.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Patience herself would startle at this letter

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And play the swaggerer; bear this, bear all:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: She says I am not fair, that I lack manners;

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: She calls me proud, and that she could not love me,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Were man as rare as phoenix. Ods my will!

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Her love is not the hare that I do hunt:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Why writes she so to me? Well, shepherd, well,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: This is a letter of your own device.

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: No, I protest, I know not the contents:

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Phebe did write it.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Come, come, you are a fool

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And turnd into the extremity of love.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I saw her hand: she has a leathern hand.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: A freestone-colourd hand; I verily did think

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: That her old gloves were on, but twas her hands:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: She has a huswifes hand; but thats no matter:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I say she never did invent this letter;

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: This is a mans invention and his hand.

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Sure, it is hers.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Why, tis a boisterous and a cruel style.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: A style for-challengers; why, she defies me,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Like Turk to Christian: womens gentle brain

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Could not drop forth such giant-rude invention

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Such Ethiope words, blacker in their effect

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Than in their countenance. Will you hear the letter?

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: So please you, for I never heard it yet;

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Yet heard too much of Phebes cruelty.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: She Phebes me: mark how the tyrant writes.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Reads

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Art thou god to shepherd turnd,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: That a maidens heart hath burnd?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Can a woman rail thus?

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Call you this railing?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: [Reads]

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Why, thy godhead laid apart,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Warrst thou with a womans heart?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Did you ever hear such railing?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Whiles the eye of man did woo me,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: That could do no vengeance to me.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Meaning me a beast.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: If the scorn of your bright eyne

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Have power to raise such love in mine,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Alack, in me what strange effect

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Would they work in mild aspect!

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Whiles you chid me, I did love;

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: How then might your prayers move!

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: He that brings this love to thee

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Little knows this love in me:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And by him seal up thy mind;

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Whether that thy youth and kind

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Will the faithful offer take

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Of me and all that I can make;

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Or else by him my love deny,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And then Ill study how to die.

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Call you this chiding?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Alas, poor shepherd!

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Do you pity him? no, he deserves no pity. Wilt

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: thou love such a woman? What, to make thee an

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: instrument and play false strains upon thee! not to

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: be endured! Well, go your way to her, for I see

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: love hath made thee a tame snake, and say this to

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: her: that if she love me, I charge her to love

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: thee; if she will not, I will never have her unless

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: thou entreat for her. If you be a true lover,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: hence, and not a word; for here comes more company.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Exit SILVIUS

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Enter OLIVER

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Good morrow, fair ones: pray you, if you know,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Where in the purlieus of this forest stands

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: A sheep-cote fenced about with olive trees?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: West of this place, down in the neighbour bottom:

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: The rank of osiers by the murmuring stream

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Left on your right hand brings you to the place.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: But at this hour the house doth keep itself;

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Theres none within.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: If that an eye may profit by a tongue,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Then should I know you by description;

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Such garments and such years: The boy is fair,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Of female favour, and bestows himself

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Like a ripe sister: the woman low

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: And browner than her brother. Are not you

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: The owner of the house I did inquire for?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: It is no boast, being askd, to say we are.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Orlando doth commend him to you both,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: And to that youth he calls his Rosalind

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: He sends this bloody napkin. Are you he?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I am: what must we understand by this?

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Some of my shame; if you will know of me

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: What man I am, and how, and why, and where

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: This handkercher was staind.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: I pray you, tell it.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: When last the young Orlando parted from you

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: He left a promise to return again

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Within an hour, and pacing through the forest,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Chewing the food of sweet and bitter fancy,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Lo, what befell! he threw his eye aside,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: And mark what object did present itself:

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Under an oak, whose boughs were mossd with age

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: And high top bald with dry antiquity,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: A wretched ragged man, oergrown with hair,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Lay sleeping on his back: about his neck

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: A green and gilded snake had wreathed itself,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Who with her head nimble in threats approachd

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: The opening of his mouth; but suddenly,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Seeing Orlando, it unlinkd itself,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: And with indented glides did slip away

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Into a bush: under which bushs shade

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: A lioness, with udders all drawn dry,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Lay couching, head on ground, with catlike watch,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: When that the sleeping man should stir; for tis

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: The royal disposition of that beast

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: To prey on nothing that doth seem as dead:

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: This seen, Orlando did approach the man

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: And found it was his brother, his elder brother.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: O, I have heard him speak of that same brother;

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: And he did render him the most unnatural

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: That lived amongst men.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: And well he might so do,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: For well I know he was unnatural.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: But, to Orlando: did he leave him there,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Food to the suckd and hungry lioness?

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Twice did he turn his back and purposed so;

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: But kindness, nobler ever than revenge,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: And nature, stronger than his just occasion,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Made him give battle to the lioness,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Who quickly fell before him: in which hurtling

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: From miserable slumber I awaked.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Are you his brother?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Wast you he rescued?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Wast you that did so oft contrive to kill him?

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Twas I; but tis not II do not shame

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: To tell you what I was, since my conversion

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: So sweetly tastes, being the thing I am.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: But, for the bloody napkin?

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: By and by.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: When from the first to last betwixt us two

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Tears our recountments had most kindly bathed,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: As how I came into that desert place:--

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: In brief, he led me to the gentle duke,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Who gave me fresh array and entertainment,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Committing me unto my brothers love;

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Who led me instantly unto his cave,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: There strippd himself, and here upon his arm

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: The lioness had torn some flesh away,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Which all this while had bled; and now he fainted

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: And cried, in fainting, upon Rosalind.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Brief, I recoverd him, bound up his wound;

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: And, after some small space, being strong at heart,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: He sent me hither, stranger as I am,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: To tell this story, that you might excuse

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: His broken promise, and to give this napkin

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Dyed in his blood unto the shepherd youth

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: That he in sport doth call his Rosalind.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: ROSALIND swoons

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Why, how now, Ganymede! sweet Ganymede!

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Many will swoon when they do look on blood.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: There is more in it. Cousin Ganymede!

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Look, he recovers.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I would I were at home.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Well lead you thither.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: I pray you, will you take him by the arm?

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Be of good cheer, youth: you a man! you lack a

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: mans heart.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I do so, I confess it. Ah, sirrah, a body would

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: think this was well counterfeited! I pray you, tell

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: your brother how well I counterfeited. Heigh-ho!

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: This was not counterfeit: there is too great

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: testimony in your complexion that it was a passion

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: of earnest.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Counterfeit, I assure you.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Well then, take a good heart and counterfeit to be a man.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: So I do: but, i faith, I should have been a woman by right.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Come, you look paler and paler: pray you, draw

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: homewards. Good sir, go with us.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: That will I, for I must bear answer back

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: How you excuse my brother, Rosalind.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I shall devise something: but, I pray you, commend

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: my counterfeiting to him. Will you go?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: ACT V

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: SCENE I. The forest.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Enter TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: We shall find a time, Audrey; patience, gentle Audrey.

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: Faith, the priest was good enough, for all the old

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: gentlemans saying.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: A most wicked Sir Oliver, Audrey, a most vile

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Martext. But, Audrey, there is a youth here in the

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: forest lays claim to you.

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: Ay, I know who tis; he hath no interest in me in

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: the world: here comes the man you mean.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: It is meat and drink to me to see a clown: by my

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: troth, we that have good wits have much to answer

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: for; we shall be flouting; we cannot hold.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Enter WILLIAM

speaker: WILLIAM
text_entry: Good even, Audrey.

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: God ye good even, William.

speaker: WILLIAM
text_entry: And good even to you, sir.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Good even, gentle friend. Cover thy head, cover thy

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: head; nay, prithee, be covered. How old are you, friend?

speaker: WILLIAM
text_entry: Five and twenty, sir.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: A ripe age. Is thy name William?

speaker: WILLIAM
text_entry: William, sir.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: A fair name. Wast born i the forest here?

speaker: WILLIAM
text_entry: Ay, sir, I thank God.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Thank God; a good answer. Art rich?

speaker: WILLIAM
text_entry: Faith, sir, so so.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: So so is good, very good, very excellent good; and

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: yet it is not; it is but so so. Art thou wise?

speaker: WILLIAM
text_entry: Ay, sir, I have a pretty wit.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Why, thou sayest well. I do now remember a saying,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: The fool doth think he is wise, but the wise man

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: knows himself to be a fool. The heathen

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: philosopher, when he had a desire to eat a grape,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: would open his lips when he put it into his mouth;

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: meaning thereby that grapes were made to eat and

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: lips to open. You do love this maid?

speaker: WILLIAM
text_entry: I do, sir.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Give me your hand. Art thou learned?

speaker: WILLIAM
text_entry: No, sir.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Then learn this of me: to have, is to have; for it

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: is a figure in rhetoric that drink, being poured out

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: of a cup into a glass, by filling the one doth empty

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: the other; for all your writers do consent that ipse

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: is he: now, you are not ipse, for I am he.

speaker: WILLIAM
text_entry: Which he, sir?

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: He, sir, that must marry this woman. Therefore, you

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: clown, abandon,--which is in the vulgar leave,--the

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: society,--which in the boorish is company,--of this

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: female,--which in the common is woman; which

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: together is, abandon the society of this female, or,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: clown, thou perishest; or, to thy better

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: understanding, diest; or, to wit I kill thee, make

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: thee away, translate thy life into death, thy

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: liberty into bondage: I will deal in poison with

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: thee, or in bastinado, or in steel; I will bandy

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: with thee in faction; I will oerrun thee with

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: policy; I will kill thee a hundred and fifty ways:

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: therefore tremble and depart.

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: Do, good William.

speaker: WILLIAM
text_entry: God rest you merry, sir.

speaker: WILLIAM
text_entry: Exit

speaker: WILLIAM
text_entry: Enter CORIN

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Our master and mistress seeks you; come, away, away!

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Trip, Audrey! trip, Audrey! I attend, I attend.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: SCENE II. The forest.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Enter ORLANDO and OLIVER

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Ist possible that on so little acquaintance you

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: should like her? that but seeing you should love

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: her? and loving woo? and, wooing, she should

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: grant? and will you persever to enjoy her?

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Neither call the giddiness of it in question, the

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: poverty of her, the small acquaintance, my sudden

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: wooing, nor her sudden consenting; but say with me,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: I love Aliena; say with her that she loves me;

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: consent with both that we may enjoy each other: it

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: shall be to your good; for my fathers house and all

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: the revenue that was old Sir Rowlands will I

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: estate upon you, and here live and die a shepherd.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: You have my consent. Let your wedding be to-morrow:

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: thither will I invite the duke and alls contented

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: followers. Go you and prepare Aliena; for look

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: you, here comes my Rosalind.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Enter ROSALIND

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: God save you, brother.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: And you, fair sister.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Exit

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: O, my dear Orlando, how it grieves me to see thee

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: wear thy heart in a scarf!

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: It is my arm.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I thought thy heart had been wounded with the claws

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: of a lion.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Wounded it is, but with the eyes of a lady.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Did your brother tell you how I counterfeited to

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: swoon when he showed me your handkerchief?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Ay, and greater wonders than that.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: O, I know where you are: nay, tis true: there was

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: never any thing so sudden but the fight of two rams

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: and Caesars thrasonical brag of I came, saw, and

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: overcame: for your brother and my sister no sooner

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: met but they looked, no sooner looked but they

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: loved, no sooner loved but they sighed, no sooner

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: sighed but they asked one another the reason, no

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: sooner knew the reason but they sought the remedy;

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: and in these degrees have they made a pair of stairs

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: to marriage which they will climb incontinent, or

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: else be incontinent before marriage: they are in

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: the very wrath of love and they will together; clubs

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: cannot part them.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: They shall be married to-morrow, and I will bid the

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: duke to the nuptial. But, O, how bitter a thing it

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: is to look into happiness through another mans

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: eyes! By so much the more shall I to-morrow be at

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: the height of heart-heaviness, by how much I shall

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: think my brother happy in having what he wishes for.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Why then, to-morrow I cannot serve your turn for Rosalind?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I can live no longer by thinking.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I will weary you then no longer with idle talking.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Know of me then, for now I speak to some purpose,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: that I know you are a gentleman of good conceit: I

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: speak not this that you should bear a good opinion

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: of my knowledge, insomuch I say I know you are;

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: neither do I labour for a greater esteem than may in

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: some little measure draw a belief from you, to do

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: yourself good and not to grace me. Believe then, if

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: you please, that I can do strange things: I have,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: since I was three year old, conversed with a

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: magician, most profound in his art and yet not

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: damnable. If you do love Rosalind so near the heart

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: as your gesture cries it out, when your brother

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: marries Aliena, shall you marry her: I know into

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: what straits of fortune she is driven; and it is

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: not impossible to me, if it appear not inconvenient

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: to you, to set her before your eyes tomorrow human

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: as she is and without any danger.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Speakest thou in sober meanings?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: By my life, I do; which I tender dearly, though I

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: say I am a magician. Therefore, put you in your

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: best array: bid your friends; for if you will be

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: married to-morrow, you shall, and to Rosalind, if you will.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Enter SILVIUS and PHEBE

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Look, here comes a lover of mine and a lover of hers.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Youth, you have done me much ungentleness,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: To show the letter that I writ to you.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I care not if I have: it is my study

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: To seem despiteful and ungentle to you:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: You are there followed by a faithful shepherd;

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Look upon him, love him; he worships you.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Good shepherd, tell this youth what tis to love.

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: It is to be all made of sighs and tears;

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: And so am I for Phebe.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: And I for Ganymede.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And I for Rosalind.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And I for no woman.

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: It is to be all made of faith and service;

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: And so am I for Phebe.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: And I for Ganymede.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And I for Rosalind.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And I for no woman.

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: It is to be all made of fantasy,

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: All made of passion and all made of wishes,

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: All adoration, duty, and observance,

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: All humbleness, all patience and impatience,

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: All purity, all trial, all observance;

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: And so am I for Phebe.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: And so am I for Ganymede.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And so am I for Rosalind.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And so am I for no woman.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: If this be so, why blame you me to love you?

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: If this be so, why blame you me to love you?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: If this be so, why blame you me to love you?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Who do you speak to, Why blame you me to love you?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: To her that is not here, nor doth not hear.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Pray you, no more of this; tis like the howling

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: of Irish wolves against the moon.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: To SILVIUS

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I will help you, if I can:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: To PHEBE

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I would love you, if I could. To-morrow meet me all together.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: To PHEBE

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I will marry you, if ever I marry woman, and Ill be

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: married to-morrow:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: To ORLANDO

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I will satisfy you, if ever I satisfied man, and you

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: shall be married to-morrow:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: To SILVIUS

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I will content you, if what pleases you contents

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: you, and you shall be married to-morrow.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: To ORLANDO

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: As you love Rosalind, meet:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: To SILVIUS

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: as you love Phebe, meet: and as I love no woman,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Ill meet. So fare you well: I have left you commands.

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Ill not fail, if I live.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Nor I.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Nor I.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: SCENE III. The forest.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Enter TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: To-morrow is the joyful day, Audrey; to-morrow will

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: we be married.

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: I do desire it with all my heart; and I hope it is

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: no dishonest desire to desire to be a woman of the

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: world. Here comes two of the banished dukes pages.

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: Enter two Pages

speaker: First Page
text_entry: Well met, honest gentleman.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: By my troth, well met. Come, sit, sit, and a song.

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: We are for you: sit i the middle.

speaker: First Page
text_entry: Shall we clap intot roundly, without hawking or

speaker: First Page
text_entry: spitting or saying we are hoarse, which are the only

speaker: First Page
text_entry: prologues to a bad voice?

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: Ifaith, ifaith; and both in a tune, like two

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: gipsies on a horse.

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: SONG.

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: It was a lover and his lass,

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino,

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: That oer the green corn-field did pass

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: In the spring time, the only pretty ring time,

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: When birds do sing, hey ding a ding, ding:

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: Sweet lovers love the spring.

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: Between the acres of the rye,

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: These pretty country folks would lie,

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: In spring time,  and c.

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: This carol they began that hour,

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino,

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: How that a life was but a flower

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: In spring time,  and c.

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: And therefore take the present time,

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino;

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: For love is crowned with the prime

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: In spring time,  and c.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Truly, young gentlemen, though there was no great

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: matter in the ditty, yet the note was very

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: untuneable.

speaker: First Page
text_entry: You are deceived, sir: we kept time, we lost not our time.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: By my troth, yes; I count it but time lost to hear

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: such a foolish song. God be wi you; and God mend

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: your voices! Come, Audrey.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: SCENE IV. The forest.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Enter DUKE SENIOR, AMIENS, JAQUES, ORLANDO, OLIVER, and CELIA

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Dost thou believe, Orlando, that the boy

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Can do all this that he hath promised?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I sometimes do believe, and sometimes do not;

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: As those that fear they hope, and know they fear.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Enter ROSALIND, SILVIUS, and PHEBE

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Patience once more, whiles our compact is urged:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: You say, if I bring in your Rosalind,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: You will bestow her on Orlando here?

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: That would I, had I kingdoms to give with her.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And you say, you will have her, when I bring her?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: That would I, were I of all kingdoms king.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: You say, youll marry me, if I be willing?

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: That will I, should I die the hour after.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: But if you do refuse to marry me,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Youll give yourself to this most faithful shepherd?

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: So is the bargain.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: You say, that youll have Phebe, if she will?

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Though to have her and death were both one thing.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I have promised to make all this matter even.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Keep you your word, O duke, to give your daughter;

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: You yours, Orlando, to receive his daughter:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Keep your word, Phebe, that youll marry me,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Or else refusing me, to wed this shepherd:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Keep your word, Silvius, that youll marry her.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: If she refuse me: and from hence I go,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: To make these doubts all even.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Exeunt ROSALIND and CELIA

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: I do remember in this shepherd boy

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Some lively touches of my daughters favour.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: My lord, the first time that I ever saw him

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Methought he was a brother to your daughter:

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: But, my good lord, this boy is forest-born,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And hath been tutord in the rudiments

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Of many desperate studies by his uncle,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Whom he reports to be a great magician,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Obscured in the circle of this forest.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Enter TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: There is, sure, another flood toward, and these

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: couples are coming to the ark. Here comes a pair of

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: very strange beasts, which in all tongues are called fools.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Salutation and greeting to you all!

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Good my lord, bid him welcome: this is the

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: motley-minded gentleman that I have so often met in

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: the forest: he hath been a courtier, he swears.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: If any man doubt that, let him put me to my

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: purgation. I have trod a measure; I have flattered

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: a lady; I have been politic with my friend, smooth

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: with mine enemy; I have undone three tailors; I have

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: had four quarrels, and like to have fought one.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And how was that taen up?

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Faith, we met, and found the quarrel was upon the

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: seventh cause.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: How seventh cause? Good my lord, like this fellow.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: I like him very well.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: God ild you, sir; I desire you of the like. I

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: press in here, sir, amongst the rest of the country

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: copulatives, to swear and to forswear: according as

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: marriage binds and blood breaks: a poor virgin,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: sir, an ill-favoured thing, sir, but mine own; a poor

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: humour of mine, sir, to take that that no man else

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: will: rich honesty dwells like a miser, sir, in a

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: poor house; as your pearl in your foul oyster.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: By my faith, he is very swift and sententious.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: According to the fools bolt, sir, and such dulcet diseases.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: But, for the seventh cause; how did you find the

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: quarrel on the seventh cause?

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Upon a lie seven times removed:--bear your body more

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: seeming, Audrey:--as thus, sir. I did dislike the

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: cut of a certain courtiers beard: he sent me word,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: if I said his beard was not cut well, he was in the

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: mind it was: this is called the Retort Courteous.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: If I sent him word again it was not well cut, he

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: would send me word, he cut it to please himself:

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: this is called the Quip Modest. If again it was

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: not well cut, he disabled my judgment: this is

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: called the Reply Churlish. If again it was not

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: well cut, he would answer, I spake not true: this

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: is called the Reproof Valiant. If again it was not

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: well cut, he would say I lied: this is called the

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Counter-cheque Quarrelsome: and so to the Lie

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Circumstantial and the Lie Direct.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And how oft did you say his beard was not well cut?

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: I durst go no further than the Lie Circumstantial,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: nor he durst not give me the Lie Direct; and so we

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: measured swords and parted.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Can you nominate in order now the degrees of the lie?

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: O sir, we quarrel in print, by the book; as you have

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: books for good manners: I will name you the degrees.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: The first, the Retort Courteous; the second, the

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Quip Modest; the third, the Reply Churlish; the

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: fourth, the Reproof Valiant; the fifth, the

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Countercheque Quarrelsome; the sixth, the Lie with

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Circumstance; the seventh, the Lie Direct. All

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: these you may avoid but the Lie Direct; and you may

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: avoid that too, with an If. I knew when seven

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: justices could not take up a quarrel, but when the

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: parties were met themselves, one of them thought but

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: of an If, as, If you said so, then I said so; and

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: they shook hands and swore brothers. Your If is the

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: only peacemaker; much virtue in If.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Is not this a rare fellow, my lord? hes as good at

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: any thing and yet a fool.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: He uses his folly like a stalking-horse and under

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: the presentation of that he shoots his wit.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Enter HYMEN, ROSALIND, and CELIA

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Still Music

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: Then is there mirth in heaven,

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: When earthly things made even

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: Atone together.

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: Good duke, receive thy daughter

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: Hymen from heaven brought her,

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: Yea, brought her hither,

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: That thou mightst join her hand with his

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: Whose heart within his bosom is.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: [To DUKE SENIOR]  To you I give myself, for I am yours.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: To ORLANDO

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: To you I give myself, for I am yours.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: If there be truth in sight, you are my daughter.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: If there be truth in sight, you are my Rosalind.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: If sight and shape be true,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Why then, my love adieu!

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Ill have no father, if you be not he:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Ill have no husband, if you be not he:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Nor neer wed woman, if you be not she.

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: Peace, ho! I bar confusion:

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: Tis I must make conclusion

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: Of these most strange events:

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: Heres eight that must take hands

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: To join in Hymens bands,

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: If truth holds true contents.

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: You and you no cross shall part:

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: You and you are heart in heart

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: You to his love must accord,

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: Or have a woman to your lord:

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: You and you are sure together,

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: As the winter to foul weather.

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: Whiles a wedlock-hymn we sing,

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: Feed yourselves with questioning;

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: That reason wonder may diminish,

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: How thus we met, and these things finish.

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: SONG.

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: Wedding is great Junos crown:

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: O blessed bond of board and bed!

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: Tis Hymen peoples every town;

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: High wedlock then be honoured:

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: Honour, high honour and renown,

speaker: HYMEN
text_entry: To Hymen, god of every town!

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: O my dear niece, welcome thou art to me!

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Even daughter, welcome, in no less degree.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: I will not eat my word, now thou art mine;

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Thy faith my fancy to thee doth combine.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Enter JAQUES DE BOYS

speaker: JAQUES DE BOYS
text_entry: Let me have audience for a word or two:

speaker: JAQUES DE BOYS
text_entry: I am the second son of old Sir Rowland,

speaker: JAQUES DE BOYS
text_entry: That bring these tidings to this fair assembly.

speaker: JAQUES DE BOYS
text_entry: Duke Frederick, hearing how that every day

speaker: JAQUES DE BOYS
text_entry: Men of great worth resorted to this forest,

speaker: JAQUES DE BOYS
text_entry: Addressd a mighty power; which were on foot,

speaker: JAQUES DE BOYS
text_entry: In his own conduct, purposely to take

speaker: JAQUES DE BOYS
text_entry: His brother here and put him to the sword:

speaker: JAQUES DE BOYS
text_entry: And to the skirts of this wild wood he came;

speaker: JAQUES DE BOYS
text_entry: Where meeting with an old religious man,

speaker: JAQUES DE BOYS
text_entry: After some question with him, was converted

speaker: JAQUES DE BOYS
text_entry: Both from his enterprise and from the world,

speaker: JAQUES DE BOYS
text_entry: His crown bequeathing to his banishd brother,

speaker: JAQUES DE BOYS
text_entry: And all their lands restored to them again

speaker: JAQUES DE BOYS
text_entry: That were with him exiled. This to be true,

speaker: JAQUES DE BOYS
text_entry: I do engage my life.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Welcome, young man;

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Thou offerst fairly to thy brothers wedding:

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: To one his lands withheld, and to the other

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: A land itself at large, a potent dukedom.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: First, in this forest, let us do those ends

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: That here were well begun and well begot:

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: And after, every of this happy number

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: That have endured shrewd days and nights with us

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Shall share the good of our returned fortune,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: According to the measure of their states.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Meantime, forget this new-falln dignity

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: And fall into our rustic revelry.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Play, music! And you, brides and bridegrooms all,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: With measure heapd in joy, to the measures fall.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Sir, by your patience. If I heard you rightly,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: The duke hath put on a religious life

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And thrown into neglect the pompous court?

speaker: JAQUES DE BOYS
text_entry: He hath.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: To him will I : out of these convertites

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: There is much matter to be heard and learnd.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: To DUKE SENIOR

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: You to your former honour I bequeath;

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Your patience and your virtue well deserves it:

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: To ORLANDO

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: You to a love that your true faith doth merit:

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: To OLIVER

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: You to your land and love and great allies:

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: To SILVIUS

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: You to a long and well-deserved bed:

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: To TOUCHSTONE

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And you to wrangling; for thy loving voyage

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Is but for two months victualld. So, to your pleasures:

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: I am for other than for dancing measures.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Stay, Jaques, stay.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: To see no pastime Iwhat you would have

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Ill stay to know at your abandond cave.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Exit

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: Proceed, proceed: we will begin these rites,

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: As we do trust theyll end, in true delights.

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: A dance

speaker: DUKE SENIOR
text_entry: EPILOGUE

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: It is not the fashion to see the lady the epilogue;

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: but it is no more unhandsome than to see the lord

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: the prologue. If it be true that good wine needs

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: no bush, tis true that a good play needs no

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: epilogue; yet to good wine they do use good bushes,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: and good plays prove the better by the help of good

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: epilogues. What a case am I in then, that am

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: neither a good epilogue nor cannot insinuate with

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: you in the behalf of a good play! I am not

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: furnished like a beggar, therefore to beg will not

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: become me: my way is to conjure you; and Ill begin

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: with the women. I charge you, O women, for the love

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: you bear to men, to like as much of this play as

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: please you: and I charge you, O men, for the love

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: you bear to women--as I perceive by your simpering,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: none of you hates them--that between you and the

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: women the play may please. If I were a woman I

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: would kiss as many of you as had beards that pleased

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: me, complexions that liked me and breaths that I

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: defied not: and, I am sure, as many as have good

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: beards or good faces or sweet breaths will, for my

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: kind offer, when I make curtsy, bid me farewell.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: ROSALIND
